title: children air pollution school run
story: Cars spew out toxic particles as they line up idling outside premises with kids on board, a study found.Pollution was higher in classrooms nearer a road and lingered outside by the playground.Experts used sensors to measure pollution from .am to .am and pm to pm outside St Thomas of Canterbury Catholic Primary in Guildford, Surrey.The main pollution source was morning school run cars — with levels of dangerous small particles almost triple those at other times.Prof Prashant Kumar, of the University of Surrey, said pollution could hang around “long after” drop off and last into morning playtime.The air quality expert said there was less pollution during the afternoon as most pick-ups were off-site and many kids stayed for after-school activities.Prof Kumar urged schools to provide off-site parking, drop-off points and to plant hedges to block dirty air.He said: “The findings will be of great concern to parents locally and further afield.“It goes without saying that our childrens health and wellbeing is of the highest priority in society and that is why we must protect them from the dangers of air pollution.”Head Neil Lewin also urged parents to “think again” about their school run trips to help cut pollution.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: europe adapting post coronavirus lockdown covid shields
story: EUROPE is beginning to slowly adapt to the new normal after the coronavirus pandemic as some nations start to ease lockdown measures.Pictures reveal solutions such as plexiglass shields in restaurants in Italy, and all-masked classes as schools reopened in Germany.Europe has been the worst impacted region in the world aside from the United States, with seven nations occupying the top ten of countries with most deaths during the coronavirus pandemic.The peak now appears to have passed for many European states - and tough questions are being asked about how toto a somewhat normal le.Il Ciak restaurant in Rome, Italy, is trialing a new plexiglass separator to allow people toto dining out again.Italy has the second highest death toll in the world, with , fatalities from an confirmed case count of ,.The daily death toll is falling - and Italy is due to begin wider easing lockdown restrictions on May .With millions people expected toto work that day, union officials have urged people not to use public transport.Companies are planning to lay on dedicated buses for workers, issuing staggered shts, and carrying out vigorous testing of employees.Officials are also planning to have shops open seven days a week in a bid to spread out the rush from shoppers.Milan City Council is also planning to widen pavements, extend cycle paths and to encourage the use of electric scooters.Italy will be the first Western nation to emerge from two months of deep lockdown, and fears loom over a potential second wave of infections.Governments and health officials will be watching the nation closely - along with a host of other countries in Europe starting to ease measures.Denmark - which has  deaths and , cases - has seen a rush of people going for haircuts as salons opened for the first time in a month as lockdown eased.Phil Olander, owner of Phils Barber in central Copenhagen, told the BBC: We are crazy busy. I mean fully booked for the next two weeks.Other businesses including tattoo parlours, beauticians, dentists and opticians are now permitted to reopen under strict health guidelines.Driving lessons are now also allowed, and last week Denmarks youngest children ed to primary school - with further measures in place until May .Spain - the third hardest hit nation in the world with , dead and , cases - has also eased its lockdown, allowing some businesses to reopen.The government has also announced looser restrictions on children, allowing them to leave the house.Construction companies have also been allowed to resume work under strict new guidelines.Germany - which has , cases and , deaths - has also allowed students due to sit exams to go back to school, and also relaxed shop closures.Car production has also restarted at some factories, and garden centres are open again.German chancellor Angela Merkel has warned le cannotto normal - and said some states had gone too far in easing lockdown measures.Belgium meanwhile is due to announce a step by step lting of the lockdown tomorrow, and France and the Netherlands are considering reopening schools.Britain currently does not have a concrete plan for easing lockdown, with chief medical officer Chris Whitty predicting measures will last until .Prime Minister Boris Johnson is facing pressure from cabinet colleagues to begin reopening Britain - but the PM fears a second wave after his overcame his own fight with coronavirus.Britains death toll rose again today to near ,, with the total number of infections approaching ,, amid hope the UK has passed the first peak.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says end lockdown safely economy
story: DAY by day our economy is being destroyed. The new forecasts are cataclysmically worse than anything yet predicted.Despite the best efforts of Chancellor Rishi Sunak and his bailouts, the collapse in our growth and the scale of job losses are starting to look apocalyptic.Previous talk of a speedy recovery once the lockdown lts has been worryingly complacent.For many it will come too late.The damage will be permanent.One top economist says it “has pushed the economy into a recession of unprecedented speed and depth”.Another says business activity has collapsed “at a rate vastly exceeding the global financial crisis, confirming fears that GDP will slump to a degree thought unimaginable”.Remember where Britain was three months ago before Covid blindsided us.We were a powerhouse with minimal unemployment, jobs at historic highs, inflation low and pay rising healthily.We are now in deep trouble, like never before,we cannot get back to work.The Sun still backs the lockdown, while there remain so many deaths and the risk of a second, bigger wave of infections which could yet overwhelm the NHS.But it is vital the Government, despite its admirable determination to save lives, maintains focus on the immense harm being done to the country’s future.It needs an urgent strategy to mitigate that, alongside one to emerge from the lockdown as fast and safely as possible.Neither HS, at £billion, or our £billion foreign aid budget can surely now be sustainable.Tax cuts look crucial to fuel a spending and jobs revival.Meanwhile the public, admirably doing its bit by staying home, must also be alive to this economic meltdown.We must follow the social-distancing rules and wear masks where needed.But we should also be clamouring to get back to our jobs before they cease to exist.CAN you imagine what we’ll look like after six months without a decent haircut When the salons reopen there will be a stampede. Hairdressers will be instantly elevated to key worker status.We’ll bang pots and pans for them in the street every Thursday at pm.Before that we’re all going to have to learn to use scissors and clippers fast.If it goes wrong at least we’ll have masks to hide behind.IT’S not often we congratulate employment tribunals for their common sense.But one saw right through tech exec Rachel Power’s claim that she was sexually discriminated against by a boss who told her: “You got balls.”Everyone  knows it’s harmless slang for having guts.As for bringing a case over it . . . that really is a load of balls.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. We have to demonstrate it actually works and stops people getting infected with coronavirus before using the vaccine in the wider population.The vaccine was developed by a team led by Sarah Gilbert, professor of vaccinology at the Jenner Institute.Prof Gilbert says she is  per cent confident the vaccine her team is developing could be ready by September.The Oxford vaccine is called ChAdOx nCoV- and is made from a harmless chimpanzee virus that has been genetically engineered to carry part of the coronavirus.The technique has already been shown to generate strong immune responses in other diseases.Meanwhile one of the volunteers taking part in the Oxford trial has spoken about the symptoms hes expecting as the trial starts today.Simeon Courtie said he was expecting to catch a fever “at worse” as he helped find a cure to the killer disease.“They think it will be something along the lines of having the flu,” he told Good Morning Britain.“You might just get very mild side effects, but at worst maybe a fever for a couple of days and some aches and pains. title: pregnant schoolgirl 14 claimed 10 impregnated expecting baby girl
story: Russian schoolgirl Darya posted a video for her , followers of her and boyfriend Ivan, , sharing the gender of the unborn baby.He popped a balloon she held with the words ‘Boy or Girl ’This unleashed pink balloons as the pair embraced and kissed.She captioned the video “Little Karolinochka” - the fond name for Karolina.Darya - now , from the town of Zheleznogorsk in Russia - shocked the world after she appeared on a Russian TV show claiming the father of her child was a pre-pubescent youngster, and shared snaps of her -weeks-pregnant belly.But medical expert Dr Evgeny Grekov who examined Ivan said: “There cannot be sperm cells. He is still a child.”He added: “We re-checked the laboratory results three times so there cannot be any mistake.”With parental permission, a troubling television show revealed the faces of the children at the centre of a case that has caused deep controversy in Russia.The boy and his parents agreed to his medical examination with the results revealed to millions of viewers when the children, Ivan and Darya, were out of the studio.She has made clear she is determined to keep the baby, and expects to give birth via caesarean.The children are said to be from dferent schools in the Krasnoyarsk Territory in Siberia but are understood to have been friends since they were younger.Cops launched a probe when the pregnancy came to light and the girls school are assisting officers.A police spokesman said: On January , , the police received information from doctors of the Federal State Budget Healthcare Institution of the city of Zheleznogorsk that a -year-old schoolgirl was pregnant.The Investigative Committee of the Russian Federation for the Krasnoyarsk Territory and the Republic of Khakassia have launched an investigation and a decision will follow.In February, reports from Russian media said Darya claimed she had invented the story about Ivan, and she really became pregnant after she was raped by a -year-old boy.But since those reports, Darya took to her some ,-plus followers on social media telling them the rape claim was “complete nonsense”.She also added there had been no DNA test to establish paternity.Police and the Russian Investigative Committee have not commented on reports that a boy, , was put under house arrest.No charges or criminal investigation have been announced.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: drivers queue costa coffee lockdown
story: DRIVERS are this morning queuing outside Costa Coffee as Brits continue to head out during the coronavirus lockdown.Traffic on roads continues to rise with those stuck at home keen to get out in the sunshine as new figures show shopping is up  per cent.A strict lockdown has been in place since March  but pictures from around the country show people leaving their homes to make the time more bearable.Dozens were seen waiting in their cars outside a Costa drive-thru in Mansfield, Notts, this morning.Meanwhile, figures from Google show between February  and March , visits to retail and recreation locations, such as restaurants, shopping centres and galleries dropped by  per cent.But by the end of last week, this was up by  percentage points to  per cent below their normal level, new stats show.Health Secretary Matt Hancock today said companies re-opening during the crisis were never required to close.Speaking this morning, he insisted they were still following the guidelines and could have continued trading through the pandemic.He today welcomed companies such as BQ, house builders Taylor Wimpey and car makers Jaguar and Nissan getting back to work.Appearing on Sky News, he said: The things that are restarting are things that we never required to close in the first place, but what the companies have been doing is working out how they can have safe working following the social distancing rules whilst people are at work.Throughout weve allowed hardware stores to stay open, and the construction industry, but what businesses have been doing is taking the last couple of weeks to work out OK, how do you stay open and stay within the social-distancing rules at work So its absolutely fine for those businesses to stay open because they were never required to close by the social-distancing rules.It comes after thousands of shoppers queued outside BQ after the chain reopened  stores during the lockdown.Hundreds were seen queuing outside a store in Ashfield, Notts, with people keen to carry out refurbishments while they stay at home.Hyde Park in London has been packed with young Brits exercising, while others were seen relaxing in the sunshine as the temperature hit C in the capital.Others were seen buying plants and gardening tools from a BQ in Leeds while pictures showed more cars on motorways this morning.Meanwhile, one group of lads ignored social distancing rules to play football in Londons Southwark Park.The picture caused concern for one minister who said there is a risk people are starting to ignore the rules.MP Brandon Lewis told of his fears people will be struggling to stick to the lockdown after so many weeks cooped up inside.He said: I think there is always a risk when you are doing something like this, particularly those living alone, will be finding it really dficult.Weve got to look at the success weve had in flattening that curve. Weve lost too many lives already.When you follow the guidelines, when you stay home, you are doing something directly personally that is not just helping the NHS, but saving lives.BQ had been closed since the end of March since the introduction of lockdown measures to try to contain the spread of Covid-.Customers had been able to use click and collect services to purchase goods after hardware stores were included on the governments list of essential retailers.The store carried out a trial in  stores over the weekend and opened them fully - with restrictions. It has now opened a further  stores.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailKey workers including teachers, bus drivers and supermarket staff will qualy for free coronavirus testing from Friday as ministers seek a way out of the lockdown. The tests, until now restricted to frontline NHS and care staff and care home residents, will now be available to up to  million across the UK. The critical workers and their families will be able to book a test on a Government websitethey are displaying symptoms. Some , contact tracers will be hired to identy those who have come into close contact with an infected person so they can be quarantined. The dramatic expansion is part of the effort to ramp up both testing and contact tracing as the Government considers how to ease restrictions. Public Health England wants the system up and running in three weeks so it can be usedthe Government wants to ease restrictions at the next lockdown review on May . Health Secretary Matt Hancock said it was part of “getting Britain back on her feet”. He added: “Testing, tracking and tracing, done effectively, can help to suppress the transmission in a way that allows you to have lesser social distancing rules.” But with testing capacity standing at slightly over , – and just , actual tests carried out Thursday – there are fears the Government will struggle to meet demand. I It remains some way off from delivering on its pledge of , tests by the end of the month, with NHS and care staff already struggling to get them.  The criteria for which key workers qualy for tests will be similar to those used to decide whose children can still attend school. They will have to display current symptoms for the tests to work, as no successful antibodies test has yet been devised. Tests will be offered at dozens of drive-through sites, at mobile laboratories or at home, with up to , kits a day sent out via Amazon. Results from the drive-through sites will be sent out by text within  hours, and within  hours of collection of the home delivery tests.  Wales has already announced plans to expand testing to key workers including delivery drivers, food production workers, utility workers and key public service staff. Another  hospital deaths were announced yesterday, taking the total to ,, though the true figure including care home deaths could be more than ,. At the daily No press conference yesterday, Mr Hancock claimed capacity for carrying out tests had expanded “ahead of our plans”. Chief Scientic Adviser Sir Patrick Vallance said the Government was “on track” to delivering , tests a day in six days’ time. There are now just  drive-through sites – though ministers promised up to  within a week – and just four mobile labs, though the Army is expected to help deliver more. Cabinet minister Brandon Lewis said: “I think it’s dreadful that we can’t get more people tested. That’s why it’s important we do upscale the ability for people to access these tests.”  But Shadow Health Secretary Jonathan Ashworth said: “We have urged the Government to do more testing and consistently questioned why ministers were not moving to a test-and-trace strategy. It is crucial that greater numbers of critical workers are now able to access testing.” It came as the first two volunteers – a microbiologist and a cancer researcher – started trials for a coronavirus vaccine at Oxford University on Thursday. One was given the coronavirus dose while another was given a meningitis vaccine for comparison. Microbiologist Elisa Granato, who took part in the trial on her nd birthday, said: “I felt like this is a very easy way for me to support the cause.” Cancer researcher Edward O’Neill said: “It seems like the right thing to do.” Prof Sarah Gilbert, leading the team, said she was optimistic about the chances of success. The Oxford Vaccine Group hopes to repeat the process with six more volunteers on Saturday, moving to larger numbers on Monday. Up to , participants will be recruited across study sites in Oxford, Southampton, London and Bristol. The Cabinet met virtually yesterday to discuss how to start lting restrictions as the UK gets through the peak of the virus. One minister told the Mirror: “Testing, tracing and tracking is now the key priority. We hope the testing will now accelerate.” Yet just weeks ago Government health experts said mass testing, as carried out successfully in South Korea, was “not appropriate” for the UK. Downing Street appeared to admit yesterday that some of the restrictions could have to stay in place until next year.  The Prime Minister’s spokesman did not deny claims by England’s Chief Medical Officer that “very socially disruptive measures” could be needed into next year. Mr Hancock has set out plans for , people in England to take part in a study to track the virus in the population and determine how many people have developed antibodies. Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty warned the public must be “realistic” that the only way back to normal le is a vaccine or treatment. He added: “The probability of having those in the next calendar year are incredibly small.”

title: coronavirus home testing kits run
story: NewsCoronavirus home testing kits run out within hours as key workers scramble to sign upTen million key workers are now being offered coronavirus teststhey need them - but just , home testing kits were available on the first day. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe first batch of coronavirus home testing kits ran out within hours today as a surge of key workers left the system mired in confusion. A limited supply of just , tests vanished off the governmentaposs website after Matt Hancock launched them for million key workers and their families. Minutes later the entire website appeared to shut down - with a message telling applicants: You can’t currently register for a COVID- test. Please check back here later. The Tory Health Secretary announced last night he would expand Covid- testing to all essential workers - including supermarket workers, delivery drivers and teachers - plus those who live with them.But Twitter was flooded with complaints today that the government website either wasnapost working at all or showing home testing kits had run out.A government source said the home testing kits were only added to the website at around am today. That meant a wave of people reported they had run out - and posted screenshots of the government saying so on Twitter - when in fact the home kits were still available. The website said: Currently, only drive-through tests are available. Weaposve issued todayaposs allocation of home test kits. Despite the confusion, todayaposs supply of home testing kits was expected to run out by around .am anyway - because of the limited number. A Whitehall source claimed: We expected to be running out on Day One. It shows the demand is there. But by am the entire website - for both home testing and drive-through sites - appeared to be shut.  Government officials were not immediately able to explain the message. And in another apparent problem, one user was told on the governmentaposs helpline that there was a glitch in verying key workersapos identities. Stevie Shillinglaw, , told the Mirror: The call handler definitely used the word glitch and was sure to emphasise it would last all day. I was told to try again tomorrow. Most people are expected to visit a drive-through testing centrethey are showing symptoms of Covid-. But these are up to  minutesapos from homes, there are only  or do up and running, and visitors must drive. For those who canapost visit a drive-through site, home testing kits were launched from today to be delivered by Royal Mail and Amazon. Yet there are only , available today, scaling up to , a day by the end of April.

title: coronavirus welsh government tightens lockdown
story: NewsCoronavirus: Welsh Government tightens lockdown restrictionsThe First Minister Mark Drakeford has tightened the rules to stop people heading to a second home for the weekend and spreading coronavirusShareByNicola BartlettPolitical CorrespondentLydia Morris:,  APR News " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Welsh government is ramping up restrictions on those tempted to travel to second homes over the weekend.Ministers say the stay-at-home regulations have been revised to continue to prevent the spread of  coronavirus. The key change however is that people now cannot now leave or remain away from their main residence It comes ahead of an announcement by the First Minister Mark Drakeford of a new framework and seven key questions to help lead Wales out of the pandemic. This will help determine when the right time comes for the stay-at-home restrictions to be eased. The government says the changes, which come into effect this weekend, will help clary that those who leave their home with a reasonable excuse - such as going to buy food, for healthcare or work - can’t remain outside to do other things. There are some new relaxed rules that also allow people with health conditions or disabilities to leave home to exercise more than once a day. This will help families with children with learning disabilities and autism in particular. The changes announced today will also allow some businesses in Wales to re-open and operate click and collect services. Mr Drakeford said that when the time is right lockdown could be left in three phases like a traffic light in reverse. The red phase would see only the most careful and controlled lting of restrictions, he told BBC Radio Wales. The amber zone would see more restrictions lted and,the virus is not re-emerging, Wales could then move to the green zone, he said. This period would look much more like the lives we had before the crisis hit, Mr Drakeford told Radio Wales Breakfast with Oliver Hides. Asked when Wales might enter the red zone, the first minister said I hope we will be in a position to do that at the end of the current three-week lockdown period. However he warned this would only happenWales had met the tests set out in the Welsh Governmentaposs framework for exiting the lockdown, which will be published later on Friday.

Health Secretary Matt Hancock set out his plans for easier, faster and simpler testing so more people can access a Covid- test to tellthey currently have the virus. At the daily Downing Street briefing, Mr Hancock said the capacity for carrying out tests was now ahead of our plans, with the ability to carry out more than , tests a day. But he still faces a huge hurdle to climb to reach his , target - almost double current levels - in a weekaposs time. Because capacity has now increased so substantially, we are now able to expand who can get the tests, he said.Our ultimate goal is that everyone who could benefit from a test gets a test. Mr Hancock said: Itaposs all part of getting Britain back on her feet. But you may have to drive for a -minute round trip to get a test and there could be heavy demand on new kits to be posted to your home. Hereaposs who is eligible and how the system will work. Who is eligible for a test  Those who the government has classied as essential workers in England and members of their households. The government say they hope that the devolved administrations will follow suit. In the UK there are around million people classed as essential workers but their households will also be eligible under the scheme. NHS staff and care home workers are already being referred for testing by their workplaces. But now other workers will be eligible. It it the same list of occupations used by the government to determine whether or not you can continue to send your children to school during lockdown. Key workers on the list are the same as those for access to schools, and include NHS and social care workers, police officers, teachers, social workers, those in the justice system, undertakers, some in local government, supermarket and food production workers, journalists, transport workers and some people in utilities and IT. A full list is below or on this web page. How sick do you have to be   You need to show symptoms in order to be tested. The main two are a new and persistent dry cough and a temperature. But other people who have tested positive for covid- include losing taste and a sense of smell.    It will showyou currently have Covid-. This is useful to proveyour symptoms are actually the virus. It does not showyouaposve had Covid- in the past. It will help people work out when they and their household members canto work safely. Where do I log on to book a test  Visit the governmentaposs web page. Where do I go to get tested     The first port of call is a drive-through testing centre -  of which are currently open, with  promised by the end of April. The government expects you to be able to drive for up to  minutes from your home to get to a drive-through site, leaving some with potentially a -minute round trip. WhatI canapost drive     For those who donapost live near enough to a testing site or canapost drive there are other options. The government has pledged that Royal Mail and Amazon will deliver home testing kits for the first time from Friday. The availability of these will be limited at first, at just , per day. Officials hope for this to scale up to , a day by the end of April. What about other ways of getting tested  Meanwhile apossatelliteapos test kits are also being sent directly to care homes to enable residents with symptoms to be tested. And the Army is helping set up mobile testing units which will travel the country to places like care homes, police stations and prisons. Itaposs not clear how these will help workers without a mobile unit or satellite kit at their place of work. How long will I wait for results     Test results from the drive-through sites will be sent out by text within  hours, the government says. For home delivery tests, the waiting time is  hours. Itaposs not clear how quickly a test will be booked in once youaposve asked for it - presumably it depends on demand. Why are essential workers getting tested  The aim is simple - to ensure they can get back to work. Because the test showsyou currently have Covid-, it also can given an indication that your cough is just a  alarm. So people whoaposve been self-isolating to protect others due to a mild cough can get back on the front line. Whataposs it like getting the test   The test involves taking a swab  of the nose and throat - and it goes back pretty far, so be prepared. A single swab is used to collect a liquid sample from the back of your throat and your nose. This swab is then placed into a sample tube and securely packaged, where it is sent to the lab for testing. Depending on where you get tested, you will either have a clinician take your swab or be asked to do it yourself.

Dean Burrows, , has spent the last  days taking to his front garden in Crewe, Cheshire, dressed as characters including Shrek, an elf and a cheerleader to showcase his best moves. The barber originally planned to jive in the garden just to put a smile on his neighbours’ faces, but when a passer-by suggested he used a bucket for donations he decided to try and raise money for the NHS too. Mark Beaumont, , has been left devastated after his we Sharon, , died after contracting the killer virus.The mum-of-five passed away on Good Friday at the Princess Royal Hospital, in Orpington, Kent. Mark has driven Gareth and the team to and from the St Georgeaposs Park training ground, Wembley for matches and airports for international fixtures, for almost five years.  Following his weaposs death Mark received an outpouring of love and support from his community with £, being raised through a GoFundMe page. And Mark has revealed how he received a call out of the blue from Southgate offering his deepest sympathies and telling him: If there’s anything I can do, all you have to do is say the word. It was a touching offer from Southgate but came as no surprise to Mark. Mark said: “We’re just like one huge family.  When you see them out there, playing at Wembley, people don’t realise what it takes to get them there, what goes on behind the scenes. “I get involved in the kit as well, laundry. I’m not just the driver. I’ve been doing it for four or five years. “And to get a personal call from Gareth, he just said ‘If there’s anything I can do or the FA can do for your family, all you have to do is say the wordapos. “It’s just nice to hear. “We’re all just get on like a house on fire, he’s just fantastic. What you see is what you get.”  Sharon was rushed to hospital on March  after she began suffering from a temperature and cough over the weekend - before losing her sense of taste and smell. And she tragically passed away in intensive care on April  despite doctors working around the clock. The mum-of-five leaves behind daughters Laura, , Chantel, , Georgia, , son Lewis,  and granddaughter Amia, two. Tragically, Mark and Sharon lost their first daughter Chloe, after she was born with spina bida, a condition where the spinal cord and spine do not develop properly. Paying tribute to his “unbelievable darling” we, who he had been to married for almost  years, Mark said: “It’s a great loss to all of us. “Over the weekend, she started to have a temperature, dry cough and lost her sense of smell and taste. “After a few days, it just didn’t seem to be getting better so I rang  and they told us to self isolate for seven days but ring for an ambulancewe needed.  “On the eighth day, about am, she just couldn’t sleep, her temperature was up and down and I just knew she’d had enough. “I rang , and they redirected us to , which I did and they asked us to go to hospital. It was quite strange, there was no one  there. I was only allowed to stay for an hour. The next day, the family were told that Sharon had been diagnosed with pneumonia.  And two days later, Mark was told that she had also contracted coronavirus. He said: It just really escalated from there. She was on a normal oxygen mask first but then it turned out that she required a lot more oxygen. So she had to go on what they call a ers mask, which looked really uncomfortable. At that point she was on FaceTime with me and the family. It was so tough because at that time, we didnapost think it was going to end up the way it did. When she was on the ers mask, she couldnapost really say a lot because we couldnapost understand what she was saying. But, you know, obviously, she was looking at us and we were telling her she could get through it.  Then Iaposve got a phone call a couple of days later to say aposIaposm really sorry, Mark, but, unfortunately, sheaposs got to go on a ventilator.apos  Then the communication had to stop, it was an agonising time.Sharon, who had high blood pressure and Type  diabetes, was put in an induced coma - which she never came out of.Mark said: It was all up and down after that. One minute she looks like she was responding and it wasnapost happening. Then sadly, her kidneys started to fail so they put on dialysis. Then, I got the dreaded phone call from the doctors on Good Friday morning asking me to go to the hospital. I went into the hospital and spoke to the consultant and the head nurse.  And they said aposHonestly and truthfully, weaposve honestly done all we can for Sharon. But sheaposs got massive organ failure and internal bleeding as well.apos So I went and sat with her and FaceTimed her mum and it was just an awful time. And I got to say my goodbyes and be there when she passed. I came out and I just felt numb and empty. It felt like I was in a dream Iaposd wake up from. Mark then had the terrible task of telling the coupleaposs children that she had passed. Mark said:  Obviously, they knew that she was in hospital and I kept them informed all the time. We all prayed, Iaposm not a religious person, but Sharon was Catholic so we had candles and we had prayers every night. On the day she passed, they knew when I went that there was nothing  they could do. It was heartbreaking. Now the dedicated dad is planning her funeral - which can only have  guests due to coronavirus limitations. He said: We can only have  at the service, which is just immediate family. So thataposs been extremely dficult although it will also be on FaceTime. Itaposs just awful. You hear about it on the news and you hear about other people that may have contracted it and itaposs not too bad But when it when it hits home, itaposs just knocked us for six and the lockdown doesnapost help. But lucky for me, Iaposve got all my children around me and my little granddaughter. Weaposre all isolated together anyway, we did that from the onset, and itaposs the best thing weaposve ever done. Now Mark says he can feel the spirit of his we keeping him going amid the tragic circumstances. He said: I think sheaposs behind me pushing me. Sheaposs obviously saying to me, aposLook, come on Mark, you need to be strong for the family,they can see youaposre strong, theyaposre not going to feel so bad.apos I think her funeral is going to be one of the worst times. The couple met at a coach station in Harlesden where they were both working. Mark said: We both worked for the same company, I was a driver and then I was taken off the road. Sharon came in as secretary to the chairman. And I turned on the charm and when didnapost work, I just asked her out. The couple were set to celebrate their nd wedding anniversary on May th. But now, ahead of Sharonaposs funeral - the devoted husband has planned one final gesture to highlight his weaposs spirit. He said:  If there was one thing that me and Sharon were famous for, it was being late. Even on our wedding day, she was late. So Iaposve requested the undertaker to be five minutes late at the crematorium. Sheaposd thank me for this and sheaposd probably be laughing. Now Mark says he has been so grateful by the outpouring of love and support for his we. He said: Iaposm just so overwhelmed I havenapost got the words to express to people. I need to put out there a huge thanks, especially in this time of lockdown, when people donapost knowthey have jobs to go back too or much money. National Hair and Beauty Federation CEO Hilary Hall said their concern was when salons could begin operating safely - for their members and clients - and acknowledged there are dangers of having such close contact. Boris Johnson ordered businesses to close on March . Brits have been left unable to get their hair cut, with many sharing images of family members stepping in to give them a trim online. Due to his condition, Mr Rex, from Stevenage, Hertfordshire, does not know about the weekly Clap for Carers event or how Britons are paying tribute to health and care staff, and therefore doesnapost take part, his son says. Mr Rex was devastated to find the note in his letterbox calling him a “hypocrite” for not clapping given that his we, Barbara, was cared for by the NHS in her final days. Have you been affected by coronavirus  Email webnews@mirror. The note, believed to have been written by a neighbour, read: Your we belonged to a stupid religion but end of days relied on NHS but you didnapost clap for them HYPOCRITES. Mrs Rex, who was a Jehovahaposs Witness, recently died of an illness. Mr Rex, who lives alone since his we passed, has dficulty understanding the situation around the coronavirus pandemic due to his advanced dementia.He is afraid he is being targeted, said his son, Christopher Hobbs-Rex, who has installed cameras outside his fatheraposs door since the incident.  Christopher is outraged about the hateful message has since uploaded a Facebook post urging the anonymous writer to come forward.He said: “He was devastated, really upset because he did not know why such a note was put through his letterbox. “He does not know about the Thursday night and what the country does for the NHS, he is scared that this person will do something  so I have had a video doorbell fitted and will have CCTV fitted shortly. “Due to the restrictions I take him his weekly food on a Tuesday, we chat and I do a few jobs for him. “My sister in law who visits him regularly telephoned me to say he had received the note one day. “I was very angry and still am, hence I why I put the post on social media, I wanted to find out who did such a terrible, cowardly thing.  “If you feel so concerned or have a grudge against my family, then please can we meet to discuss this so I can tell you the truth. “Everybody has a right to their own religion evenwe do not agree, this is freedom of speech. Do not attack other people especially under cover of the night sneaking around and to the vulnerable and elderly who are disabled and clearly do not fully understand what is going on.” Millions of Britons took part in the weekly Clap for Carers on Thursday night as they paid tribute to key workers including NHS and care home staff.  Hundreds once again gathered on Westminster Bridge in central London to show their support. Photos showed some in the crowd standing less than two metres apart, drawing criticism from Twitter users. The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and their three children, Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis, joined the UK for the fth week in a row, to praise everyone from NHS workers to teachers who are continuing to work during the lockdown. The family took to their doorstep at their Norfolk home, Anmer Hall.The Prince of Wales and Duchess of Cornwall, who are currently staying at their Scottish home Birkhall, also took part in the clap. The Duke of Cambridge appeared in a comedy skit with Stephen Fry prior to the pm clap. During the exchange, he said that homeschooling his children had proved a bit of a nightmare, really. He added: By the way, have you seen anything good on TV  Itaposs hell without EastEnders.  Before getting up to take part in the clap for carers, he said: On my way, let me just seeI can find my socks, and my shoes, and my trousers. Footage of the duke clapping outside his home with his family was then aired as the clap for carers began. At Daisy Hill hospital in Newry, a convoy of dozens of buses drove past and sounded their horns in appreciation of healthcare workers. Nurses and doctors, some joined by family members, came out of the hospital to watch the noisy thank you from Translink drivers.

The Duke of Sussex emailed the family of Holly Smallman, , to say he had been “fortunate” to meet their “special and happy girl”. Holly had suffered from conditions such as epilepsy, cerebral palsy and chronic lung disease since birth. The teenager met Harry in  when he presented her sister Ruby with a Wellchild Award for being her carer. After learning of Holly’s death, Harry messaged her parents, Hayley, , and Gary, , to send his “deepest and most heartfelt condolences”. He added: “I imagine words cannot really hope to provide much comfort to you and your family at this most dficult of times, but I wanted you to know that you, your daughter Ruby and son Josh are in my thoughts and my prayers.”Hayley said: “For Prince Harry to find the time to send this email, to know Holly made that impact on him and that he cares so much, even in all his private turmoil, just meant the world to us.”Harry asked to meet Holly at the  event, when he was only meant to meet Ruby, now , and her mum. Hayley, from Liverpool, said: “I told him she was visually impaired and got frightened of people talking over or down on her.  “When she came in, he got down on one knee, held her hand and had a full conversation with her, chatting away. “He sent everyone  out of the room and just spent time with the two of them. It was an incredible moment.” Because of the lockdown, only a handful of mourners could attend Holly’s funeral but the family asked supporters to wear pink instead.

He writes: For any of these patients, delay can be a death sentece. In addition, the NHS has cancelled most routine surgeries for three months. Thataposs tens of thousands of people who must endure further pain and distress as they wait for the operation or procedure that might dramatically improve their quality of le.Follow all coronavirus updates here on our live blog Dr Sikora said affected patients have become collateral damage in the war against coronavirus .The cancer specialist said he has witnessed empty wards in NHS hospitals and eerily silent theatres.Writing for the Mail, he said while the coronavirus dominates the healthcare system at the moments, the next health disaster will be the millions at risk after being neglected.Dr Sikora added: If this continues for six months, I suspect that in years to come there will be at least , excess cancer deaths. Health bosses have denied a report that transfers of patients with Covid- to the newly built NHS Nightingale in London were rejected due to a lack of nurses. According to reports, applications by several London NHS trusts to move patients to the new facility in Docklands were rejected as there were too few nurses to treat them.

The two-minute clip - in which the cameraman yells - itaposs huge, wow, unbelievable - shows the killer storm cutting through the towns of Ardmore and Springer. Tornadoes and other storms also swept through Texas and Louisiana on Wednesday and Thursday. More than , people across Oklahoma and about , people in Onalaska, Texas, faced power outages. Images in local media showed the devastation caused by the storms, including damage to homes, downing of power lines and twisted billboards. A factory worker leaving Oklahomaaposs JI Manufacturing was killed when a suspected tornado hit and his body was found four miles away, Marshall County Emergency Management Director Robert Chaney said. Motorist Chad L. Weyant, , was also killed in the stateaposs city of Madill when the same suspected twister blew his vehicle off a highway, reported Oklahoma Highway Patrol. Another man in Louisiana was also reportedly swept away in drainage water as he went to retrieve his rubbish bin, according to local media reports.A total of nine suspected tornadoes ravaged southern Oklahoma, National Weather Service meteorologist Alex Zwink said. Three people died and at least  were injured when the tornado touched down in Onalaska emergency officials said. Onalaska is about  miles north of Houston. Two people were also killed in southern Oklahoma, while Rapides Parishaposs Office reported that a woman died on a bridge in a storm in Woodworth, Louisiana. Onalaska resident Charles Stephens told the Houston Chronicle that he and his we were trapped for  minutes in their bathroom after a large pine tree fell through their roof.  While Louisiana State University tweeted all students were safe after storms caused damage on the Alexandria campus. On April , a tornado struck the city of Onalaska and other portions of Polk and San Jacinto counties, and possibly even far eastern Walker County, Houstonaposs National Weather Servicesaid in a statement. NWS said it was sending crews on Thursday morning to survey the path of the Onalaska tornado.  Polk County, where Onalaska is located, issued a declaration of disaster on Wednesday night after the tornado hit. Texas Governor Greg Abbott said that the state had deployed response teams and medical resources to provide assistance. Daria, , who has since become a social media influencer, revealed to her , followers that her baby will be a girl. The girl from Zheleznogorsk, Russia, also announced that she will call her Karolina. Her -year-old boyfriend Ivan - who experts have said is too young to be able to father a child - was also at the gender reveal event. Ivan popped a balloon Daria was holding with the words ‘Boy or Girl ’ As it popped dozens of smaller pink balloons rose into the air, as the young couple hugged and kissed each other. She captioned the video “Little Karolinochka” - a pet name for Karolina. Earlier Daria, now , had posted a picture showing her lump when she was  weeks pregnant.first revealed Dariaaposs story back in January when she announced to the world that she was expecting a child with Ivan.The pair appeared on Russian TV with their parents as doctors dismissed the possibility that Ivan could be the dad. The young couple told the captivated audience they had fallen in love at first sight and were happy to be having a child together. Daria, who was just eight weeks pregnant at the time: A friend of mine introduced us and two days later we started dating.  Ivan said he was in love with me. We tried to spend as much time together as we could. We like walking down the streets holding hands and kissing. But Dr Evgeny Grekov, a urology and andrology expert, says Ivan could not be the father. He said: We rechecked the laboratory results three times so there cannot be any mistake. There cannot be sperm cells. He is still a child.  There is even no testosterone. And just to add, he still has childish sex organs. Puberty has not started. So we have a lot of questions. Daria said: People call me a w**** and accuse me of sleeping with everyone around.

title: dundee fc john nelms phone call spfl vote
story: A Dundee fans group are “happy and satisfied” chief John Nelms acted in the best intentions of the club after clear-the-air talks.The Dark Blues managing director took centre stage in the pantomime that has engulfed Scottish football following the SPFL’s proposed plan to end the - season in the lower isions and dish out much-needed prize money.That was after the American’s initially-intended “no” vote changed to a “yes” to allow the resolution to pass in exchange for firm promises on league reconstruction five days later.That sparked an outcry from the club’s fans over the U-turn which saw Dundee United crowned Championship winners.And the Dundee Supporters Association – which is made up of  clubs comprising , members – sent an email to the Dens supremo asking for “clarity” over the change in position and how it would benefit the Dark Blues.Nelms responded with a club statement to reiterate he “got the best deal possible out of a situation that was going to be bad for us in any iteration proposed” and followed that up with a phone conversation with DSA chairman Kenny Ross.The DSA committee then released a statement stating they were pleased that the push for league reconstruction shows Nelms and owner Tim Keyes “are in this for the long haul”.The statement included: “We were pleased that the club not only released an updated statement later that day but that managing director John Nelms also personally contacted a member of the DSA committee by phone.“Mr Nelms was more than able to adequately explain the club’s thought processes and position and demonstrate how he was able to get the best possible outcome for Dundee Football Club in an impossible situation.“When Dundee realised their vote hadn’t been cast on April , the dynamic changed and it is clear to the DSA that Mr Nelms has worked tirelessly since and as a result of the SPFL releasing the results of the ballot before all of the member votes were in, was put in an unfair, undemocratic and dficult position.“With regards to league reconstruction we suspect that none of the  SPFL chairmanpushed harder for it than John Nelms and, as a result, a working party has been established to discuss it, which was not on the table in the original resolution.“It would not have been convened had Dundee voted ‘No’ as they had originally intended and this has to be a good thing and in the best interests of Dundee FC.“We were therefore pleased to learn that John himself will be on that working group and gives proof,any were needed that John and Tim Keyes are in this for the long haul.“The DSA are therefore happy and satisfied that Mr Nelms worked in best interests of both Dundee FC and Scottish football in general and got the best possible outcome for our club in a very dficult situation.“The Dundee FC Supporters Association has had a good working relationship with Mr Nelms and his board in recent years and we are grateful that he responded to our request swtly and satisfactorily and look forward to this relationship continuing in the future.”EXCLUSIVE: John Nelms answers fan worries saying #yes# vote got best possible deal for Dundee" title: dundee united dave bowman monchengladbach jim mclean
story: Dundee United legend Dave Bowman believes their  win over Borussia Monchengladbach trumps Barcelona and Roma as the club’s greatest-ever result.United saw off the Germans - at the Bokelberg Stadion  years ago today to reach the Uefa Cup Final thanks to second-leg goals from Iain Ferguson and Ian Redford.They had beaten Barca - on aggregate in the previous round, while a -  European Cup semi-final first-leg win over the Italians at Tannadice is in the history books despite United not making the final.However, Tangerines hero Bowman remembers the Monchengladbach result with most fondness.“Monchengladbach were a really big team at the time, both them and Barca were, but I think the big thing was Monchengladbach got us into a final,” the former United midfielder said.“Nobody remembers who loses the semi-final. I wasn’t there at the time but nobody really remembers the Roma European Cup semi-final too fondly but they’ll always recall Barcelona and Monchengladbach.“Getting into the final was a massive thing for the city and the club but at the time, as players, nothing was really a surprise for us.“We were expecting to get there so when we did it was great to do, don’t get me wrong, but it wasn’t as much of a surprise to us as it was outsiders.“At that time there was the European Cup, Cup Winners’ Cup and the other teams went into the Uefa Cup.“When you think about that in recent terms, Liverpool didn’t win the league last season but they won the Champions League.“That was the sort of level we were up against. It was a huge achievement.”Bowman recalls United going into the second leg riled up after witnessing some premature celebrations from the Monchengladbach players after a stalemate in Dundee.The -year-old also remembers a rare occasion where legendary boss Jim McLean inidually congratulated his players after the final whistle.Bowman, who made  appearances in tangerine, added: “Under wee Jim we were always taught, unless it was the second leg and you had to win at home, as long as you didn’t lose a goal it was OK.“That was the biggest thing, from our point of view, we didn’t get beat and we weren’t up against it.“I remember they were celebrating after the first leg and that probably gave us a bit of impetus to go on and beat them.“They were high-fiving each other because they got a - and thought the tie was over so that annoyed us a bit.“It made such a dference for us going there at - and Iain getting the goal just before half time.“They had to really come at us because they needed to score two.“Going into half time it was a massive advantage but I can’t really remember us being under that much pressure.“We knew they had to score two which was a tough ask against our defence. It was quite comfortable.“They didn’t have a lot of chances. Big Thommohad some great games and made some big saves that season but I can’t really remember him having to be brilliant.“Heggiesaid to me after it, ‘You should take this all in,’ and I was probably very naïve and just thought this happens every year, we’ll do it again next year.“I probably didn’t appreciate it as much as what I probably should have. It’s only when you look back.“It’s probably one of the only times I can recall Jim coming round and shaking everybody’s hand in the dressing-room after the game.“He really pushed us to our limits and got the best out of everybody. If he could see you had something he would get it out of you, how he did it was irrelevant.“He was very guarded towards us but he went round and congratulated everyone inidually.”United went on to lose the final - over two legs against IFK Gothenburg, with a - Scottish Cup Final defeat to St Mirren sandwiched in between.Bowman believes had they beaten the Buddies they might’ve gone on to secure the Uefa Cup, too.He continued: “It shows how much the SFA helped us at the time! We played the Scottish Cup Final on the Saturday and the second leg of the Uefa Cup Final on the Wednesday.“It was for the good of Scottish football we were trying to win it as well. I thinkwe’d beaten St Mirren, we would’ve had a lot better chance.“There’s no way of saying we’d have definitely beat Gothenburg because they were a decent team but the St Mirren loss was the first down we’d had that season.“Everything was on the up all the time, even with the amount of games we’d played that year.“It was the first time the press had questioned our fitness because we’d played that many games.“You’re never tired when you’re winning but as soon as you get beat that can quickly change.“Personally, all the finals don’t mean anythingyou don’t win. You want to have success by winning and savouring that.”🔵 In these troubled times, when many people are struggling to get out for their paper, we are pledging to help readers by providing a FREE digital edition of the Eveningfor three months. title: lee wilkie dundee fc dundee united reconstruction spfl
story: It’s great to see talks have already begun over league reconstruction and I’m glad they will be speedy ones – getting all this mess behind us will be for the better.Even a global pandemic can’t stop the drama that continually surrounds Scottish football.This past couple of weeks have taken the biscuit, though.I read Ann Budge’s comments recently about getting the plans in place as soon as possible and, for me, that’s the right idea.The quicker we get things sorted the better for everyone – clubs can plan ahead for whatever ision they will be in and there will, at last, be some clarity over what the future holds.Evenwe don’t know when the game will .I suggested a few weeks back that revamping our set-up to include  teams in the top flight would be a way to stop anyone being unfairly damaged by the coronavirus shutdown.I stand by that. In an ideal world I’d like to see an even bigger league with Dundee given the chance to join United in the Premiership.Whether that can happen, we’ll have to wait and see.We’re right at the start of the process so I’m sure almost anything is still on the table.I hope all the clubs in this area get something out of reconstruction. What we get should be better for Scottish football.I just hope we can avoid the same sort of voting farce we had  days ago with the SPFL.Dundee and managing director John Nelms were left in an impossible position, evensome of the behaviour has been questionable.As far as I’m concerned we should move on now and look to a better future. Ideally one with United and the Dark Blues in the top flight together.I know the existing Premiership clubs would certainly want the Dee up, too.What we know for sure, having seen the goings-on for the past couple of weeks, is clubs will only vote for something that is in their own interest. That’s just the way the world is.The good news, I think, for Dundee in all that is having them catapulted into the top flight would be seen to have plenty of plus points for it.Just ask Aberdeen – having both our city clubs back in the top flight gives them more decent away crowds coming to Pittodrie and their fans good away days.They wouldn’t be the only ones that benefit from having the Dundee derby back in the Premiership.We need the biggest teams at the top table – make it happen!It’s a few days ago now but I want to offer my congratulations to Robbie Neilson and his team after Dundee United were crowned Championship winners.The Tangerines have been in pole position right from the first whistle and it’s more than deserved for all at Tannadice.We don’t know what the top flight might look like come next season but the main objective has been achieved by Robbie – get United back in the big time.That’s been the target for four years now.It’s taken far longer than anyone associated with the club would have liked but they’ve finally done it.With all the noise going on over the past couple of weeks over the season, just having their top spot confirmed must be a huge weight off their shoulders.With the way the world is, relief will be the main feeling I’d bet for Robbie, Tony Asghar and Mark Ogren.They’ve done their bit – now it’s about improving the team for a shot at what is likely to be a bigger Premiership next campaign.Well done United!Having only seen the info that’s come out in the press, I’ve found Dundee United’s fall-out with a supporters’ group strange.It sounds like the money the Dundee United Supporters’ Foundation were looking to put into the club would be a benefit for everyone at Tannadice.There’s obviously been a disagreement behind the scenes but it doesn’t sit right with me having a go at your own fans – and on the day before the club were crowned champions, too.Jackie McNamara being up and about again was great to see last week. We were together in Scotland squads and he helped me a lot at that time. It’s fantastic to hear he’s on the mend again after a real health shock.🔵 In these troubled times, when many people are struggling to get out for their paper, we are pledging to help readers by providing a FREE digital edition of the Eveningfor three months. title: aberdeen race for life postponed due to coronavirus
story: A popular Aberdeen charity race has been postponed due to the coronavirus.Cancer Research UK#s Race for Le Aberdeen was due to take place at the Beach Esplanade on Sunday June .However due to the ongoing pandemic, the organisers have decided to postpone the event.Participants who have already signed up for the Race for Le will be contacted directly by the charity.It is unclear when the event could be rescheduled for but a decision will be announced as soon as possible.Lisa Adams, Cancer Research UK spokeswoman in Scotland, said: “As the coronavirus outbreak continues to unfold, we are listening to the advice and guidance of the Scottish and the UK Governments carefully.“While our priority is ensuring that people affected by cancer get the support and information they need during unprecedented times, we’re having to work quickly to understand the impact the pandemic will have on Cancer Research UK’s fundraising.“We have urgently reviewed our events, including Race for Le. As the safety of our supporters, volunteers, suppliers and staff across the hundreds of Race for Le events due to take place in  is incredibly important we have made the decision to postpone the events scheduled in May, June and July including Race for Le Aberdeen this June. We will aim to deliver as many events as possible later in the year.“We know this will be a huge disappointment to our supporters, but I’m sure they will understand. We’ll be in touch with everyone who has signed up as soon as possible to let them know next steps.“Since it began, Race for Le has raised over £m for Cancer Research UK’s le-saving work. We’re incredibly grateful to everyone who has taken part and hope their support will continue.”

title: my lockdown diaryby nico sutherlanddrumoak school
story: My name is Nico and I am seven and go to Drumoak School.We have been doing lots of cycles and walks and lockdown has been quite fun.My teacher Miss Hutcheon gives me jobs through an app called Seesaw. We always have maths and literacy and then we sometimes do drama or a topic or other fun activities.In the Easter holidays I had some work from my mummy because she’s a teacher and then we had a week with no work and my daddy was on holiday with us.On April  Miss Hutcheon told me to put on my school unorm but it was an April Fool and I fell for it.It felt weird wearing my unorm in my house to do my jobs.We have had lots and lots of Facetimes with friends and family.At the weekend we had an online quiz with some of our neighbours.My favourite part of lockdown has been when I had a sleepover in the sitting room with mummy and daddy and we stayed up until pm and ate popcorn in bed.I am missing my friends and I’m really excited about when lockdown is over.We want to hear how the lockdown is affecting the youngest members of our society. title: the 10 aberdeen imports you may have forgotten about1
story: Over the club#s -year history, there have been influential foreign imports # from Zoltan Varga to Arild Stavrum # who have left their mark on Aberdeen.Recently, we compiled a list we deemed to be the  best overseas players in Dons# history, which you can find here:Who are the  best foreign imports to star for Aberdeen " src"https:www.eveningexpress fp sport football aberdeen-fc donsnews who-are-the--best-foreign-imports-to-star-for-aberdeen embed # secretwoKtOdfV" data-secret"woKtOdfV" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"The  players above all won trophies, made a large amount of appearances for the club and or lit up Pittodrie in seasons when there wasn#t too much domestic talent to shout about.There are even more memorable foreign players who just missed out on the #best# list, Theo Ten Caat, Cato Guntveit, Peter van de Ven, Willem van der Ark, Eugene Dadi and Roberto Bisconti among them, who had an enduring impact on the Red Army.However, the list below is for the less successful imports, some who left after just a handful of appearances, and others who have just faded from memory.Now based in Canada, the pacey Bermudan # who signed for the Dandy Dons aged  in the the early s # was a regular for the reserves, but was stuck behind Charlie Cooke in the inside left pecking order under Tommy Pearson.Lewis, , ed to Bermuda after two years, suffering from homesickness. However, he made a mark in his homeland, with ex-West Ham United striker Clyde Best going on record to say he had travelled from Bermuda to England after being inspired by Lewis. Trailblazer.The most memorable thing about the Dutch centre-half, who joined on loan from De Graafschap in January , is probably his somewhat funny name.He joined compatriots Karim Touzani and Jeffrey de Visscher in Jimmy Calderwood#s squad and the Reds had first refusalthey were interested in a permanent move. They weren#t.In the end, Bus made three starts, although he did find time to score an own goal against Inverness Caledonian Thistle # a performance then-EE columnist and club legend Stewart McKimmie described as #simply woeful#.Midfielder Fabiano made nine starts for the Dons in the   season under Ebbe Skovdahl and then Steve Paterson.The Frenchman had formerly been at PSG and Swansea before arriving at Pittodrie.Made similarly few appearances in the French lower leagues after his Reds spell. Safe to say, a career that never really got going.Denmark#s Ravn was in double figures for starts in   and   # his two seasons at Pittodrie, under Tommy Pearson and then Eddie Turnbull.Played his part with goals in the run to the Scottish Cup semi-finals in his second season, but has been obscured by success of compatriot Jens Petersen in the same side and # later # Henning Boel.Ravn ed to former club KB Copenhagen after leaving the Granite City. He died in  at the age of , having worked for brewer Tuborg for decades.Another Calderwood Dutch import, Feyenoord loanee Snoyl was at Pittodrie for the final six months of the   campaign.Calderwood wanted the pedigree winger # who was left-footed and skilful, but prone to drt out of games # on a permanent basis for the following campaign, but the fee demanded by Feyenoord scuppered the deal.Now , he went on to have spells with NAC Nijmegen, RKC Waalwijk, NAC Breda and Budapest#s Ujpest.Belgian de Clerck only played two games in goal for Aberdeen # but still managed to score for the club.His moment of Reds glory came on his debut in the League Cup against Berwick Rangers at Shielfield Park, a tie which the Dons won - on aggregate, in August .The former Twente Enschede keeper # deputising for Jim Leighton, who never scored in  appearances for Aberdeen # launched a huge kick, which bounced once before sailing over Berwick keeper Keith Davidson’s head and into the net.De Clerck#s later career saw himto playing his football in Holland.Faroese midfielder Hansson, who was  when he made his sole appearance for Aberdeen under Mark McGhee, is a rarity on this list in that he has had a decent career where.Now  # and after spells at HB Torshavn, Aalborg, Vikingur and Vendsyssel FF # he has established himself at Danish Superliga side AC Horsens, making more than  appearances. He is also a -cap international and counting.Italian forward Billio started his career at AC Milan and, via a long list of clubs including Dundee, made his way to Aberdeen.He penned a short-term deal after being frozen out at Dens Park, making five starts, but couldn#t agree terms with incoming boss Steve Paterson to stay longer and spent the rest of his career in Italy#s lower leagues.His only goal  in the   season came in a - win at home against Dunfermline.Nigerian forward Uchechi played twice for the Reds in the second half of the - season under Craig Brown.Had moved from Abia State in Nigeria to join Charlton#s youth academy in his early years, before a move to West Ham, then Leicester and subsequently Sheffield Wednesday.Signing after a trial, Uchechi showed in flashes during his limited game time what he could do, but clearly didn#t make the grade with a very experienced boss in Brown.He has spent the rest of his career in English non-league football, and # at  # is currently with Hornchurch in the Isthmian Premier League.Later a Trinidad and Tobago internationaland first choice at Millwall, Liverpool-born goalkeeper Warner was on loan at Pittodrie for a few weeks in  as a stop-gap due to injuries to the other Reds keepers.He made three appearances.Warner, like Hansson, went on to have a great career, turning out for the Lions, Cardf, Fulham, Leeds, Barnsley, Tranmere# the list goes on and on.He is currently the goalkeeping coach at Accrington Stanley.

title: argyll sport decimated amid coronavirus response
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe coronavirus response has forced the cancellation of sporting events up and down the region.Just when the situation will settle down enough to allow sport to re-start is anyone#s guess at this stage, but early casualties have included shinty, football, athletics and a planned youth football trip to Europe.The committee of Mid Argyll Athletic Club took the dficult decision to postpone the Argyll final of Sports Hall Athletics which was due to take place at Atlantis Leisure in Oban this Sunday, March .With more than  young boys and girls qualying for the final from the four local area competitions and the possibility of another -plus family member spectators filling the games hall the organisers felt it was sensible to postpone the event.A statement from the organisers said: #After consultation with the management staff at Atlantis Leisure it was decided it was best to follow the guidance that is currently being issued by the Scottish Government and others to attempt to restrict the spread of the coronavirus.#We will revisit a date for holding the competition once the coronavirus situation is clear andnecessary this may be have to be after the summer school holidays. The boys and girls who qualied from the local area competitions in Lochgilphead, Oban, Tobermory and Campbeltown will be advised of the new Argyll final date and times through their local club or school.#We apologise for any inconvenience and disappointment this postponement may cause to the young athletes and their families.#The annual Crinan Puffer # an .-mile race between Crinan and Ardrishaig # has also been postponed.A fundraiser for Mid Argyll Community Pool organised with the help of Mid Argyll Athletic Club, the run was due to be held on Sunday March .Announcing the postponement, Kirsty Young of Mid Argyll Community Pool said: #In light of current government guidelines to avoid non-essential contact and unnecessary travel we feel that this is the right decision to make.#I will be contacting all stakeholders involved with the organisation and running of the event in the coming days to try and come up with a date to re-schedule the event.#Months of work to raise money for a trip to Holland in April for young Mid Argyll footballers has come to nothing, thanks to coronavirus.Lochgilphead Red Star  players, coaches, parents and supporters were left disappointed when the Amsterdam tournament was cancelled.A committee spokesperson said: #The team are devastated not to be going after nine months of fundraising for the event. We are lucky enough to be getting a full refund from the organisers and at present are awaiting to seethe same will happen regarding the flights.#We would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone from the public to businesses who have supported us throughout our fundraising, from attending coffee mornings, donating at bag packs and online donations and our hypnotist night. Your generosity has been overwhelming .#We plan to let the kids of the team decide which charities they would like to donate the funds to once we receive the refund.#After just one week of the  season, shinty#s governing body, the Camanachd Association, made the decision on Friday March  to postpone all matches until further notice.The association also recommended that this should include all training, festivals and other events.In a statement, the Camanachd Association said: #In light of the government restrictions on public gatherings and the resulting pressure on emergency services and healthcare provision, the Camanachd Association has postponed all fixtures under our auspices whilst a further assessment can be made and to reduce any additional pressure our activities may have otherwise had on emergency services.#The wellbeing of the people in our communities is primary in this decision and we hope that this decision removes any expectations or pressures on participating during a time that we can be focused on doing all we can to suppress the spread of the virus.#The recommendation is that shinty clubs should hold any meetings using remote technology such as Skype.The association statement concluded: #We will endeavour to provide due notice to clubs ahead of any future shinty matches so as there is time to restart training.#The Scottish Football Association also decided to suspend all matches in the interests of public health for the and health and safety of players, match officials and staff across the game.Ian Maxwell, SFA chief executive, said: #This is of paramount importance as the country enters the #delay# phase of the coronavirus pandemic.#The decision to suspend or continue training is at each club’s discretion at this time, however clubs must ensure to follow the current medical guidance issued by the government and the health authorities when making this decision.Scottish Rugby decided that with effect from Sunday  March at pm there would be a short period without domestic competition or training up to March .This includes rugby in all domestic league and cup fixtures, training, festivals and other rugby events as well as the FOSROC Super tournament, which come under Scottish Rugby#s jurisdiction.The Scottish Rugby age grade programmehas been cancelled with immediate effect for the remainder of the season.A Scottish Rugby Spokesperson said: #We have taken on board all expert medical advice before now and we are taking a precautionary approach to give time to assess what the impact of coronavirus will be on Scottish society in the coming weeks before deciding on next steps.#
