title: letters to the editor march 27 2020
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Like so many residents of Islay and Jura I was shocked to read that the Daily Mail has published an article siting areas that are the #best boltholes# for escape from the Corona virus. Included in this is the Isle of Jura.This is as shockingly reckless as it is offensive.The Isle of Jura is not a #bolthole# as the Daily Mail has chosen to state but a very beautul island steeped in culture and rich history.On both Jura and Islay we, like so many rural areas, are struggling to deal with all of the challenges related to the Corona virus out break. Our local health services have very limited resources as it is, along side a population that has many elderly residents who are more at risk to the virus.We have seen a local uptick in people traveling to Islay in camper vans and this is happening at a time when the UK government is advising against non essential travel.Those who are choosing to travel to our islands of Islay, Jura and the many other islands in Argyll and Bute in order to avoid the coronavirus may end up inadvertently spreading it to islands who arenot as much affected in the same way as so many built up urban areas are. Such actions are as reckless as they are selfish and I would implore people who do not need to travel to our rural constituency to avoid doing so until this global pandemic has passed.Jura, Islay and the rest of Argyll are some of the most beautul places you will ever visit and you won#t find an area where the people are more hospitable and friendly but while this crisis is ongoing I would ask everyone who is not currently living here to avoid traveling here for the time being.Councillor Alastair Redman # Kintyre and Islands ward.To the Scottish public,During this time of unprecedented uncertainty, we are all concerned about the safety and wellbeing of our families, friends and colleagues.Our hearts go out to those who have been affected personally by the outbreak of coronavirus , as well as the many communities around the world that are facing extreme measures in an attempt to slow its spread.We appreciate and are mindful of the challenges iniduals are currently facing as well as the impact this pandemic has had on our vital emergency services as well as the grocery retail sector, supply chain and producers.Like our retail partners, we want to take this opportunity to assure you that Scottish farmers, auctioneers, hauliers, processors and butchers are doing everything they can to maintain the ongoing availability of fresh, locally sourced Scotch Beef PGI, Scotch Lamb PGI and Specially Selected Pork.We would like to thank all those who work in the Scottish red meat industry and their families for their ongoing and unwavering efforts to keep our supermarket shelves and butcher shops stocked, fuelling Scotland with top-quality red meat during this challenging time.As bodies supporting the Scottish agricultural and red meat industry, we are constantly reviewing the developing situation and are doing all we can to support everyone involved in putting nutritious food on your plates.Alan Clarke, chief executive, Quality Meat ScotlandMartin Morgan, executive manager, Scottish Association of Meat Wholesalers Duncan Todd, secretary, Scottish Beef Association Jen Craig, president, National Sheep Association Scotland Penny Montgomerie, chief executive, Scottish Association of Young Farmers Clubs and Gordon King, executive manager, Scottish Craft Butchers.What on earth is going on  It was banal enough when Ben Goldsmith # English financier and environmentalist # tweeted that #overgrazing# by upland sheep farmers, was responsible for the devastating floods in South Wales, rather than record-breaking torrential rainfall.Unbelievably we now have a government official, Dr Tim Leunig, suggesting the whole of the UK does not need farming, and his comparison of the UK to Singapore in this context is absolutely ludicrous. You truly have to wonderthere is something in the water that he is drinking – could it be flood contamination Surely, every person having a full and ing set of neurons and synapses, the complete opposite is the truth, as we dearly need our hard working farming community.The UK Government should be fully supporting the farming industry and indeed, good land management. The Welsh Assembly has totally lost its way with its mindless policy of devastating Welsh forests with thousands and thousands # an understatement # of trees being felled for wind farms, and compounding the felony by covering acres of land with very limited electricity generating solar parks # Wales is not the Sahara and the sun disappears at night! Solar  will generate about  per cent of their maximum capacity in the UK.Returning to farming perhaps some kind person should tell Dr Tim Leunig that the answer lies in the soil and then lead him to a darkened and quiet room so he can lie down and contemplate the truth # wise men recognise that truth is the daughter of time, not of authority.Dave Haskell, Cardigan.

title: the voyages of the fulmar part 10
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsWhat a night! All of us were agreed that never had we experienced anywhere a worse one and we were glad we had been in Loch Aline on Sunday night not in Tobermory as intended as, from what we heard, that night had been similar but twice as bad.It was a wild night lashing with rain and a big swell was rolling in from the north-east causing us to pitch and roll horribly. Everything banged and rattled and the ropes, despite their lashings, slapped on the mast, the chain rugged continuously on the bobstay, and there was one most annoying thump that kept everyone awake .We could not trace its origin until in desperation the Pilot donned oilskins, sou’wester and seaboots, and went on deck and found it was the tiller end bumping on the bulwarks. The Pilot had a very justiable grouse about this as he had suggested lashing the tiller, but the Skipper had said that he did not think it necessary and that we would lie easierit was allowed to go free.About six we heard Murdoch in Venture hailing us and the Skipper and Pilot hurried on deck. The yachts in the harbour were all lying higgledy-piggledy owing to the swell, to there being little or not wind, to the strong surface current from the swollen river, and to it being about the turn of the tide.Venture and Fulmar were lying stern to stern and what had aroused Murdoch was that the Venture had got her mizzen boom over our main boom and as we pitched we had lted it up crutch and all – how nothing was broken was a miracle. She had then swung round and her now free boom had knocked the cap off our jackstay. As the Skipper came on deck Venture again surged towards us and started pitching and her counter came down with a terric slam not six inches from our bulwarks. We put our helm over and swung clear.Murdoch and Barclay were both in their dog-house and the Pilot and Skipper stayed in ours until the new tide took charge and the boats began to swing in normal fashion and all were able to retire once more to their bunks. Luckily the rain had cleared off shortly before this episode took place.At a quarter to eight we heard the usual poor forecast but for the first time since the cruise began there was not a gale warning for any area. The glass had risen well during the night. What wind there was was from the north-west.The Skipper went ashore for the milk and rolls. The dinghy had a lot of water in it and owing to the rolling it was impossible to get into it and balance on the thwarts till it was baled so the Skipper got his feet thoroughly soaked – the simple remedy of wearing seaboots had never occurred to him. Again the rolls were sold out and again he had to take porter biscuits.On board the Pilot lit the fire then started in to get our breakfast of bacon and egg. After our meal the sky cleared and it became a beautul sunny day, and everything we had was up on deck drying off or airing. The owner of Rose came alongside and for a good time tried to get us to persuade him to go north against his better judgement, but when we heard he had the lady member of his crew of three sick in her bunk our advice was that he go south and that immediately and reluctantly he was forced to agree and half an hour later he sailed. Hervor also went out about the same time and she turned north and we were to meet her later in Iona.

title: worldwide ceilidh community sign up for tunes in the hoose
story: Fiona ScottUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsCapercaillie founder Martin MacLeod, originally from Oban, and his son, also Martin, have came up with an innovative way to connect musicians from all over the world and allow them to play together for the enjoyment of others.#Tunes in the Hoose# was inspired by Scottish musician, and family friend of the MacLeods, Peter Wood, who was posting videos of himself playing tunes in his home during self-isolation.Having saw the footage Martin senior, called his filmmaker son to askhe had the technology and know-how to put a video together of him playing along to Peter’s video.#I run my own production company based out of Glasgow, so it’s relatively straight forward work for me ,# said Martin Junior.#From that first successful attempt, our new idea was to create an online community for all Scottish musicians to help them connect and continue to play together during these uncertain times.#Housed in Facebook, Tunes in the Hoose amassed over  followers last week with ,+ views worldwide. Musicians, including Martin senior and Peter, have been contributing from all over the world, including UK, USA, Australia, Canada, India and across Europe.#Tunes in the Hoose is acting as a replacement for social gatherings, networking, gigs, ceilidhs and festivals, as everyone can contribute and enjoy from their own homes during lockdown,# added Martin Junior.#The process of sustaining the online community is incredibly  time consuming. I run the main page and private group, respond to hundreds of messages per day whilst curating and creating each inidual video, which each take - hours to produce.#A common misconception is that we are doing this either via livestream, or through some kind of app- when in reality it’s very complicated work which is why you don’t see anyone  with a project like this .#One of the latest pieces to be put up features Oban accordionist  Donnie MacCorquodale playing four jigson his accordion acompanied by fellow Obanite Clare Jordon on Keys. Others joining in the session are Matthew Maclennan on keys , Martin MacLeod Snr on double bass , Peter Wood on nd boxand Rory Grindlay on drums . https:www.facebook  videos  Other notable examples from #The Hoose# include:A musician in Canada playing a tune and a  year-old Highland dancer joining in the fun: https:www.facebook  videos  A young boy in Shetland who couldn’t play for his school show , with a band of musicians filled in the gaps: https:www.facebook TunesInTheHoose videos  A virtual ceilidhfor the public to dance at home on Friday night : https:www.facebook TunesInTheHoose videos  Most viewed video: https:www.facebook TunesInTheHoose videos  #We’ve only been running for  days, so there are plenty more tunes to come,# added Martin junior.#We’ll just have to see what the future holds and hope that I#ll be able to sustain things when this situation blows over. Perhaps a Tunes in the Hoose festival!#

title: donald clark a tribute
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsDonald Clark was for  years the convivial, larger-than-le host at The George Hotel in Inveraray, a notable bon viveur and one of the most colourful characters in Argyll. He died aged  on January  after a short illness.Latterly, his mobility hampered by a leg injury, he would sit in the corner of The George public bar on an over-sized carved wooden stool. From his throne he dispensed news, advice and anecdotes – albeit not always historically accurate. His inimitable irony, perfectly-timed humour and the occasional reprimand to a wayward customer were all fuelled by a generous glass.As former president of the Scottish Licensed Trade Association and Keeper of the Quaich, Donald knew the intricacies of the business intimately from personal experience. His taste was eclectic and his appetite substantial, extending from Dom Perignon and Saint-Émilion Grand Cru to Tennent’s lager and Glen Dronach single malt. On a hot day he’d have an icy Martini or a gin and tonic, proportionately scaled up in a pint glass. Being askedhe had time for a quick ‘small one’, he would reply: #I’ll decide the size for myself,you don’t mind.#The records suggest that his frequent claim to be Scottish Slimmer of the Year, after getting his weight down from  stone to  stone, was fancul.Big D, as he was often called, was fastidious about standards in the little public bar, training his regulars to clear tables of empty glasses and plates promptly, and to keep the log fire stoked on winter evenings.If one of his regulars turned up untypically well-dressed, Donald would raise an eyebrow in mild surprise:  #What’s the occasion for the suit   A funeral   Your latest marriage   Or has your court case come up #In summer, an erratic stream of foreign tourists would have their first encounter with a Scottish pub, standing in the doorway bewildered as to what happens next – sit or stand  Fight their way to the mobbed bar or go to a table and wait for the non-existent waitress  Donald would call them over to his corner and was soon plying them with drinks, food and conversation, not infrequently paying the entire bill for his astonished guests.When a tourist asked him about the quaint red GPO telephone box in Church Square, he told them: #We have the fastest modern communications here – telephone, teletext and tell Donald.#Donald was a Francophile and loved his summers in Collioure, where #Le Grand Ecossais# was almost as well-known as in Argyll. A fixture of the local bars and restaurants, and frequently crossing the border to patronise Spanish hostelries, he revelled in the region’s seafood, wine and culture.His hobbies included cooking, opera, reading and lively conversation on a sweeping range of topics from local history to civil engineering. His knowledge was genuinely wide, but when occasionally encountering someone with a superior command of the topic in question, he would quickly change the subject and admonish: “Och, you’re showing off now.”Donald Clark was born on  July , in Rotten Row hospital, Glasgow. He was the youngest child of Donald Clark and Elizabeth Inglis, following by nine years his only sibling, Fiona.His early years were spent in Inveraray where family le revolved around his parents’ hotel in the little white-washed town.He was schooled at Inveraray Primary and Larchfield in Helensburgh, then Strathallan from  to  where he acquired his love of sports. Contrary to what his dimensions in later le would suggest, he was athletic when young, excelling at rugby and playing for his school and West of Scotland First XV and the old boys’ As.Donald also enjoyed curling, motor boating, snow skiing and water-skiing, where his party piece was to mono-ski down Loch Fyne while drinking a pint of beer.Although not a shinty player, he used his sports experience to coach the Inveraray team in the s and like his father chaired the club. In , he flamboyantly arrived in Inverness by helicopter for Inveraray#s Camanachd Final against Kingussie.

title: return to normality not on the cards sturgeon
story: Ellis ButcherUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsAto normal le before the coronavirus is #not on the cards# in the near future, Scotland#s First Minister has warned today.Nicola Sturgeon made a series of announcements as she spoke ahead of the publication of a new government report looking at potential next steps.Some businesses in certain sectors may be able to reopen but onlythey can #change how they work# to keep employees and customers m apart, she said.Schools may have to change how they teach, with not all pupils attending school at the same time or schools being subject to major redesign to keep pupils m apart, she warned.#Limited outdoor activity# might be able to restart ahead of indoor activity, but #dferent approaches for dferent areas,# may be brought in.Some form of longer term #shielding# for older people and those vulnerable to COVID- is almost certain to be required, she added.#What I have set out there is not firm decisions,# she told the briefing. #But they do illustrate the kind of options we will be assessing.#She said any lting of restrictions would have to be #careful, gradual, incremental and quite small#.It would require #ongoing monitoring,# and in extreme cases #reversed# with restrictions ed.Mrs Sturgeon said: #Ato normal as we knew it is not on the cards in the near future and it is really important that I am upfront with you now about that.#The concern is that lting restrictions too soon could see coronavirusand #run rampant,# # overwhelming the NHS and costing more lives.#What we will be seeking to do is find a new normal,# she said.#A way of living alongside this virus but in a form that keeps it under control and stops it taking the toll we know it can do.She accepted the lockdown was harming the economy, living standards, children#s education, physical health, mental health and wellbeing.Indeed, she acknowledged there are fears the restrictions may be storing up a potential health timebomb.#We must try to find a better balance than the one we have right now,# she said. #As we do so, we cannot and we must not take our eye off the need to suppress the virus and minimise the damage that it does.#Continuing to suppress COVID- is the central objective. We cannot guarantee no one will get this virus in the future, far from it.#An assumption that it is somehow safe to allow a certain proportion, or section of the population to get the virus is not part of the approach we will be taking.#We are increasingly confident measures we are taking now are suppressing the virus.#

title: borders-families-urged-stay-home-bank-holiday-weekend
story: A MINORITY of Borders residents continue to visit public places even when there is ldquoabsolutely no need.That is the view of Scottish Borders Council chief executive Tracey Logan, who urged households to respect lockdown guidance over the Easter Bank Holiday weekend.She said: ldquoLets be clear:you dont abide by this guidance you arent only putting your own le at risk - youre endangering the lives of other people.Warnings have also been issued by NHS Borders, Police Scotland and at least one local MSP.NHS Borders director of nursing and acute services Nicky Berry said: "We are at a critical stage in the fight to stop the spread of the coronavirus. Now, more so than ever, we need you to stay at home.Meanwhile, Chief Inspector Stuart Reid, whose remit is the Borders, said the ldquovast majority have made changes to their daily routines.But he suggested fines could be issued to those flouting the lockdown rules.ldquoOfficers and the public must take a common sense approach to this unique emergency. We will always encourage compliance but, as a last resort, we will use the enforcement powers which are in place, said Mr Reid.Borders MSP Rachael Hamilton called on constituents to avoid the temptation to roam the countryside.She said: ldquoWe are urging everyone to follow advice and exercise close to your home - non-essential journeys to the countryside are not permitted at this time.

title: borders-family-homesick-stranded-india
story: A BORDERS family stranded in India during lockdown are desperate to get home.Rosemary Singh flew out to Punjab with her husband Manny and their one-year-old son Jason at the start of March for a family wedding.But since India imposed measures to curb coronavirus, the trio have been anxiously waiting for the chance tohome to Galashiels.Rosemary, originally from Innerleithen, told us: ldquoThrough the whole thing my emotions have been all over the place ndash one minute Irsquom happy, the next Irsquom crying and homesick."The family were supposed toon April , but then a raft of flights were cancelled. They are currently staying with Mannys parents in Punjab.Rosemary said: ldquoWe obviously knew about coronavirus before we flew out, but we made the decision to travel as we were attending Mannyrsquos brotherrsquos wedding."We saw on the news that flights were being cancelled but we didnrsquot think it was going to happen during our stay.The family became faced with a dilemma ndash fly home and miss the wedding, or stay and risk not getting a flight.Explaining the final decision, Rosemary said: ldquoWe couldnrsquot leave. There were flights home that I couldrsquove travelled on but it wouldrsquove just been for me and my son and I wasnrsquot leaving without my husband.Chartered flights have now opened for bookings to fly Brits back home, but the Singh family remain nervous.ldquoWe will be told  hours before we are due to flywe have a seat on one of the flights next week, said Rosemary.ldquoIrsquom not building my hopes up. We might be lucky, especially as we have a baby and both mine and Jasonrsquos visas have expired.And getting a flight home is not the only hurdle the family face. ldquoIf we do get a seat on the plane, it will be flying to London. Irsquom worried about how we will get back to Edinburgh to collect our car, said Rosemary, who added network issues make it dficult to speak to people back in Scotland.Movement within India is currently very restricted, Rosemary said.ldquoThings are not too bad where we are staying but the lockdown rules are much stricter than Scotland.The UK Government is working with the airline industry and host governments across the world to help bring back British travellers.The Foreign Officersquos Minister of State for South Asia and the Commonwealth, LordAhmad of Wimbledon, said: ldquoWe are doing all we can to get thousands of British travellers in India home. This huge and complex operation also involves working with the Indian Government to enable people to move within India to get on these flights.Over  people arrived from Goa on Thursday morning, , more will arrive over the Easter weekend and these  flights next week will bring back thousands more.Borders MP John Lamont said: "Irsquove been assisting a number of Borderers to get back to the UK."My team and I have been in regular contact with this family. Earlier today one of my team spoke to Rosie to let her know about the new flights that the UK Government is providing from India, including one covering the Punjab where this family are currently located.

title: letter-editor-pick-border-telegraph
story: THANK you for visiting the Borderwebsite.Your interest in our articles reminds us that, even in these challenging times, there remains a faith in the importance of local news.Our small editorial team- working from home - is always delighted to hear your tales of success, keen to give you a  to inspire others.Those sparks of light are perhaps as vital to readers now as they have ever been in our letimes.All the while, though, we shall continue to perform that other greatof journalism - monitoring the exercise of power.Because even during this shutdown, when the usual rules do not always apply, big decisions will still be taken and our lives will still be affected.In short, the Borderand its staff want to serve you - our readers - as effectively as possible through the virus-era and beyond.However, our ability to do that depends on your support. Thank you again for visiting our website, a service we are proud to maintain, but I would also invite you to purchase a print edition whenever you can.You might even wish to start picking up an extra copy for your neighbour, especiallythey are elderly or vulnerable.Many newsagents are offering home delivery services - perhaps that is another option worth exploring.And do not forget that we also produce an e-edition of the newspaper, a page-by-page replica of the physical copy, which you can download for  pence through this link.With your backing and encouragement, the Borderwill weather this storm - allowing us to print your smile on the other side.Thank you again and best wishes,Andrew McQuarrieContent Editor

title: hawick-librarian-turns-declaration-arbroath-scots
story: A SCHOOL librarian has produced what is believed to be the first accessible Scots translation of the Declaration of Arbroath.Thomas Clark, of Hawick, worked alongside friend Ashley Douglas to complete the piece, which is now displayed on the website of the National Library of Scotland.Mr Clark, , told us: ldquoWhat was really gratying was seeing so many people realising theyrsquod been missing a Scots translation.The th anniversary of the Declaration of Arbroathrsquos creation was on April . The documentrsquos most famous excerpt is a statement of Scottish independence.Mr Clark, who works at Hawick High School, has previously completed Scots translations of a number of popular books.The focus of his latest effort, however, was rather dferent in style to previous inspirations, which include Diary of a Wimpy Kid.It took Mr Clark and Ms Douglas around three months to convert the Declaration into our native language.Asked where his interest in Scots came from, Mr Clark said it was his move to the Borders  years ago which kick-started his love affair.ldquoI spoke Scots in Hamilton and so did my friends but I was under the impression it was just bad English ndash it was knocked out of you, said Mr Clark.ldquoBut then I came to the Borders and found that a lot of people not only spoke Scots, but spoke it without a social stigma.Reflecting on the Declaration, Mr Clark believes Scots have a strange relationship with the document.ldquoItrsquos funny that we have this text thatrsquos basically the birth certicate of the whole country, but therersquos not a lot of knowledge about it, said Mr Clark, going on to outline his views on its signicance.ldquoAt root, itrsquos a revolutionary document. Itrsquos a country asserting its right to be a country and its right to choose its own ruler.ldquoWe should be a lot more proud about Scotland being one of the first countries to assert itself in this way.Mr Clark says he supports Scottish independence, but he is keen for the Declaration to appeal to nationalists and unionists alike.He said: ldquoI think itrsquos really important the Declaration of Arbroath is not part of a political wrangle. People of every stripe in Scotland should see this as being part of the heritage.

We are processing applications and payments as soon as possible, but I would reiterate once again that it is essential that the application form is completed fully and all relevant additional information provided to make the process as quick as possible for all concerned.Last week, she said the council had been ldquoinundated with applications.She added then that the aim was to process submissions within  days.Chairman of South of Scotland Enterprise Russel Griggs said last week: ldquoIt is great that payments are starting to be made to eligible businesses.Funding takes the form of pound, and pound, grants. title: toys-tablets-trampolines-additional-support-kids
story: CHILDREN with additional needs are embracing new toys, trampolines and tablet devices after a support group secured pound, in National Lottery funding.Borders Additional Needs Group , which assists more than  families, is aiming to boost its reach during the coronavirus pandemic.It has purchased sensory toys, special equipment, tablets for youngsters unable to see friends or family due to social-distancing, trampolines, outdoor equipment, and compression blankets.The charity is also hoping to purchase tablets for parents with limited access to such resources.BANGs chief executive officer Pauline Grigor told us: "During these challenging times of social restrictions, ASNchildren can find this particularly dficult due to their sensory needs. This funding will offer some support for them and their families."We have dedicated telephone support lines receiving calls from families in distress and anxiety."We are working with partner organisations, Meeting of Minds, and EPIC, to collaborate and coordinate a Scottish Borders-wide response."Since lockdown began, the volunteer-led group has been working the phones and social media ndash and providing delivery and outreach services.During the Easter Bank Holiday weekend, they even dropped off a selection of Easter eggs to Borders families."I took eggs to those I could reach," Pauline said. "The kids were delighted ndash one said he wanted to give me a hug and was sad about not being able to."BANG is currently made up of eight volunteers ndash down from its usual team of  ndash who work  hours a day. Many regular volunteers have taken time away from the charity due to the ongoing COVID- crisis, with some acting as parent carers or shielding.Pauline added: "BANG is a community of unsung heroes."NHS workers, cleaners, and truck drivers are all amazing, but we have volunteers working tirelessly behind the scenes because they care about the community."The latest funding has allowed the charity to approve support applications from  families over the last  days, delivering  sensory toys to children in need.Howevr, a further blow to the charity has been its inability to celebrate success at last months National Youth Awards, where it won the Equality and Diversity award for its BANG Summer Camp.At the awards, service user Olivia Robertson, , joined Pauline at the ceremony in Glasgow, even running on stage to collect the gong. Pauline told us that although Olivia had started the night feeling anxious due to a sensory reaction to the environment, by the end of the night she was talking away with journalists. She even called her mum after stepping off stage, saying: "Mum, Im living my best le".Pauline added: "Money cant buy that night. Seeing her boosted confidence and self-esteem exceeded the award."In the midst of the lockdown, however, BANG has received some good news after being told their funding for the BANG Summer Camp  had been approved."We will be running it," said Pauline. "What the service looks like, were unsure. But theres more of a need for it now for respite than last year."For more information, and to apply for support from BANG, visit: www.bordersadditionalneeds.org

title: teacher-makes-ppe-borders-home-schools-3d-printer
story: A TEACHER is making safety gear for key workers from the kitchen of his Peebles home.Alan Gray, who works at Gracemount High School in Edinburgh, has been producing personal protective equipmentusing a D printer.With a we employed by the NHS as a nurse, Mr Gray told this newspaper he has "a bit of an idea" about frontline workers need.He said: "They are doing a great job and deserve whatever PPE or assistance can be provided.Mr Gray ndash a craft, design and technologyteacher ndash said he decided to take home the schools printer before lockdown so he could print pupils projects.But now the machine is pumping out around  safety visors per day, according to Mr Gray, who was inspired by other teachers tales.He said: ldquoI had been hearing from both Scottish and UK social media teaching communities that teaching staff and technicians were coordinating an effort to manufacture PPE for key workers with the resources they had to hand."Teaming up with other Borders-based staff, Mr Gray began printing with the aim of supplying mainly Peeblesshire-based care workers and the Borders General Hospitalin Melrose.ldquoI used Facebook to try to raise funds to cover the cost of ordering consumables for the task, said Mr Gray. ldquoBut the community response has been overwhelming. Generous financial donations to the cause have totalled over pound. Other donations have included a local supply of printer filament, laminated pouches and hole punch, which has been invaluable."Struggling to keep up with demand, Mr Gray was joined by graphic designer Barry Turner, as well as Norman MacLeod, who designs and manufactures drones.Mr Gray said: ldquoLocal demand for face visors has been huge and I can only print in the region of - visors a day."Two other local people, Barry and Norman, hearing about the problem of supplying PPE to the front line, as well as having access to the necessary equipment, have kindly joined in D printing to try to increase the numbers available.Although the project was spearheaded by one man, it has continued to grow with the support and generosity of the community, the help of volunteers, and, of course, Gracemount Highrsquos printer.Mr Gray said: ldquoI actually brought it home to figure out how to use it and itrsquos easier to print pupilsrsquo projects at weekends. I didnrsquot know there would be a PPE shortage. It was just luck really.

title: peebles-dancers-enjoy-online-classes-lockdown
story: DANCING queens and kings across Peeblesshire have kept their toes tapping during the lockdown thanks to online classes from the Fiona Henderson School of Dance .After holding their last face-to-face class on March , FHSD has been forced to go digital with classes for pupils.In the first week of virtual classes, beginning March , FHSD ran a total of  sessions, including those for their Little Stars, Irish dancing beginners, and their graded ballet and tap pupils.School principal Fiona Henderson told us: "We did some initial planning in anticipation of having to move some classes online but that weekend was a whirlwind of activity getting all the technology in place, new timetable finalised as well as ensuring all the teachers were trained and established in their new home-studios."Fiona has praised the schools ability to transition with ease during what was predicted to be a dficult time for the dance school.All classes are up and running online, with teachers leading pupils over the video conferencing app Zoom. The only class which has not been carried across to the app is Acrowhich was axed due to health and safety concerns."Itrsquos important that pupils retain their fitness and general wellbeing during this lockdown period," said Fiona.ldquoOur classes are lsquobusiness as usualrsquo as far as it is possible using the online classrooms."Our pupils are continuing to learn ndash each class will be focusing on dferent things in dferent subjects and grades, but in general they will be continuing to learn technique, exam syllabus content and routines for their forthcoming shows and performances."Fiona added: ldquoThe lockdown is affecting people in dferent ways. I know all our teachers are really missing our pupils, so itrsquos great being able to see them and be with them lsquovirtuallyrsquo in the meantime.Every -minute class has to begin on the hour to make the most of the teaching. And theory-based work has also been introduced to enhance each session.All pupils have to be in the class, in their unorm, five minutes before the start, and are still given homework and at-home practices to work on before their next class.Like many other businesses during the COVID- crisis, FHSD is facing financial problems. But dancers families have been nothing but supportive.Fiona said: "The support from our pupils families has been fantastic and wersquove received lots of lovely messages over the last couple of weeks saying how great it is that our pupils can continue their dancing during the current restrictions and how much it means that they can continue to lsquobe withrsquo their teachers and dance friends.And as the classes have continued, maintaining a sense of normalcy for many of the pupils, one dancer said, "I want to thank you and your team for the fantastic effort all of you have put in to arrange online classes for the students during this dficult time," and another added, "I just wanted to say a huge thank you to you and your teachers for doing what you are doing!! I really enjoy the classes and appreciate all your hard work.",params: .push"Planning too far ahead in the current environment is impossible," added Fiona."The teachers and I are simply focused on our pupils and providing them with the best dance tuition we can."Wersquore all looking forward to getting back to face to face classes ndash and therersquos sure to be a party atmosphere for our first day back in our dance studios."In the meantime, though, wersquore all just aiming to keeping dancing!"For more information, visit: www.fionahendersondance

title: feature-animal-adoptions-borders-put-hold
story: PETS in need of new homes in the Borders are having to wait for their fairytale endings.The coronavirus outbreak has temporarily put an end to animal adoption across the country.The Borderspoke to four animal rescue centres in the region to learn how they, their volunteers and the animals are coping during the lockdown.Borders Pet Rescue, the providers of our pet of the week feature, looks after a iety of animals, ranging from cats and dogs to exotic reptiles and birds ndash all in need of homes.Lee-Ann Lackie, rescue centre manager, told us: "We are fortunate to have very supportive foster homes that we are using. We have three dogs and three cats in foster that were in place before the lockdown. We are trying to support them as much as possible."Unfortunately, the lockdown means that we cannot re-home any animals at this time. We had people lined up to come and meet two of the dogs on the week that the country went into lockdown and had to cancel their appointments due to this."Also, Pal, who has been waiting for over a year for a new home, was due to go away to his new home that week which has had to be put on hold. And we have no idea when he can finally go to his new home."And the centre isnt just coping with the stress of caring for the animals during a crisis, theyre also facing potential financial strain as the weeks progress."Our centre relies heavily on income generated from our four shops," added Lee-Ann. "Seventy per cent of our annual income is generated via the shops so loss of income is a real concern."We have had to cancel fundraising events during the key fundraising period of spring summer. This includes our Annual Dog Show in May which is one our biggest fundraising events."We are hopeful that not all staff go down with virus at same time."We are managing the situation to the best of our ability and [despite] that our weekly income has reduced very signicantly, and we need people to donate to help keep our centre operational whilst our shops are closed."All our animals are still being looked after and cared for by our excellent and committed staff."Sonia Graham from Borders Greyhound Rescue added: "Were trying to make the best of the situation."We have  dogs at the moment because we cant get dogs in or out. Its dficult."Weve had some under fostering, but unless they are greyhound people they wont be going to foster."Its frustrating because for people who want dogs, youd think this was the perfect time to have one as theres time for one-on-one training."And a lack of volunteers is a key factor in the dficulties facing the Greyhound Rescue now, with the charity normally taking in up to  regular helpers to care for  dogs."Without volunteers, its been a real struggle," said Sonia. "Were family-run and we have a farm too, so were just trying to fill the gaps left by volunteers."Another problem which has reared its head for Sonia and her family is the knock-on effect of this lockdown.Sonia explained: "People who may have lost jobs or their business, they wont be thinking of taking on an animal."People cant afford to pay vet bills. I can see this being a dficult year."If anything, we may see animals being handed in. People will misjudge and panic about the situation. And it wont just be dogs being brought to rescues but being dumped."It will be interesting to see how this all works out."And to help ease the strain on the rescue, Sonia has created an Amazon wishlist for donations to help keep the dogs fed.The wishlist gives donors the option to either donate physical items, such as a bag of food, or they can gt a cash amount straight into the Greyhound Rescues account to spent on vital products.On the other hand, the Arthurshiel Rescue Centre, in St Boswells, hasnt seen an increase in their four-legged residents, with the charity manager Shona Middlemass saying: "Were managing fine".She added: "Weve not had an influx of animals, any strays that get raised with us we share over Facebook."Fingers crossed everything keeps going smoothly, weve not had any problems."We dont have any cash coming in. Cat and dog boarding is our main source of income."Wed normally have five or six dogs, And Easter last year we were full with ten cats boarding."We rely on people going on holiday, and weve now had cancellation right up to July."However, the rescue has received some good news recently.Border Terrier Teddy, who went to a foster home last month, has been dubbed a failed foster, as he is likely to be kept by his foster family, finding his forever home.And its not just your average pets who are being impacted by the pandemic.The Scottish Borders Donkey Sanctuary, which was due to reopen for the Spring season in mid-March, still has donkeys available for adoption and sponsorship, and is operating as business as usual.John from the Sanctuary said: "We hope to continue routine hoof trimming, tetanus booster injections , worming and de-lousingas and when they are due on a welfare basis."All the rescues are doing their best to meet social-distancing guidelines while also ensuring the well-being of their animals.Borders Pet Rescues Lee-Ann added: "Please do not come to the centre and only contact centre by phone or email and the staff will help you as much as they can."If members of the public have any donations for the centre or charity shops, then we ask that you please keep them until it is safe to deliver them."People can donate via our Facebook and web page."For more information on these four rescues, you can find them at: Borders Pet Rescue, www.borderspetrescue.org Scottish Borders Greyhound Rescue, www.greyhoundtrust.org.uk Arthurshiel Rescue Centre, facebook Arthurshiel-Rescue-Centre- and The Scottish Borders Donkey Sanctuary, donkeyheaven.org

title: ex-radio-borders-dj-went-rome-become-priest
story: A Galashiels priest-in-training has spoken to the Borderabout his time in the Vatican and what it was like being filmed by the BBC for a new documentary, which is being aired this weekend.Former Radio Borders DJ Bobby Taylor was in his fth year at The Scots College in Rome when filming for the BBCs Priest School began in September . He is now coming to the end of his sixth year.The -year-old, whose mother is Catholic, had always had the inclination to become a priest, even applying to train before, but for reasons-unknown never followed up on these applications.It wasnt untilgoing to confession in Melbourne in , not long after the passing of his father two years earlier, that he started seeing a path to priesthood laid out clearly in front of him ndash particularly thanks to guidance from his own parish-priest in Galashiels.When we spoke to Bobby, who is back in Galashiels, he told us: "Since filming ended, the most visible thing thats changed is that when were in Rome now were wearing collars. Candidacy is the final step before being admitted as a member of the clergy. So I suppose our wardrobe is the most visible change."When you get into sixth year especially, you start realising youre closer to the end of your time in Rome than you ever have been."Although seven years, when youre in your first year, feels like a very, very long time, when you realise youre a year or maybe  months away from finishing up, you realise just how quickly its all gone ndash how little time youve got left in a beautul city like Rome."Youre looking even more forward than you ever were to getting back and doing what it is that you went to Rome in the first place to do, which is to become a priest."The programme follows a group of young Scots over a year of their seven-year degree, showing the inner workings of the seminary, its history, and how the young seminarians navigate their journey to priesthood.The colleges training isnt for every student, however. The school has an approximate  percent drop-out rate as the young men learn more of what God is calling them to do, and as they face the sometimes hard-to-accept vows which they must take."Every guy is dferent," said Bobby. "To be honest, Im not  percent sure  percent is the rate of drop out Ive experienced over the past few years Ive been there. Theres only been two or three guys out of - whove left."Me, personally, my first year was probably my toughest year. It was a big adjustment from that freedom I had, and having gone from earning quite a healthy wage working at sea, then going to seminary in a foreign country ndash it was quite a challenge."There was a period where I did have to really, seriously, pray about it and think about what I was being called to do."I think everybody goes through it, and I think its a good thing that everybody goes through because ultimately thats what seminary is about.,params: .push"Seven years isnt a number plucked out of mid-air, its a period where youre doing a lot of study but youre also doing a lot of work to understand what it is youre being called to do, andits being called to priesthood because its not a light undertaking, its quite a serious undertaking ndash but a good one, and a positive one."And the problems facing Bobby and his fellow seminarians have only grown since the COVID- lockdown.He added: "From about six weeks ago being in Rome and studying in the university with my class of about  other guys, Im now sitting in a dining room in a Catholic church house in Galashiels studying on my own."So things have changed quite a bit. But study still continues, its not like theyve stopped. Theres been a couple of weeks, this week and last week, which would have been the Easter holidays anyway."Although we may be spread out, back to our home countries, were still persevering with study."And in June, Bobby hopes to sit his exams which will see him move into his seventh year at the Scots College. However, he intends to continue with a further year of study once his seven years are over to focus on his specialist course.Priest School will be broadcast on BBC Scotland on Sunday, April , at .pm and will later be available on BBC iPlayer.

title: borders-golf-club-asks-donations-ensure-survival
story: A BORDERS golf club fighting to survive the coronavirus pandemic has raised thousands of pounds in the coursersquos th anniversary year.Torwoodlee Golf Club, near Galashiels, has launched an online fundraising page in a bid to stay afloat.Club chairman Robin Brydon told the Borderthat generous donors gave a total of pound, within seven days.Mr Brydon said: ldquoItrsquos been amazing and wersquore all totally humbled by the donations so far.The JustGiving pagedescribes the parkland course as one of the ldquofinest in Scotland, but goes on to outline the challenges faced by the club, which closed last month.A statement reads: ldquoDue to the devastating COVID- pandemic crisis affecting us all, the club now faces an uncertain future and we therefore need as much money as possible to survive the pandemic and beyond.Speaking to this newspaper, Mr Brydon revealed that the original aim was to generate pound,, but a wave of donations has prompted the target to be raised to pound,.Mr Brydon said: ldquoFor people who are not going to the golf club at the moment and spending money on teas and coffees and entry fees and who are maybe financially better off as theyrsquore not spending money, wersquod be gratefulthey could donate a little bit every week to the club.Asked what the money will be spent on, Mr Brydon said: ldquoIt all goes into the pot and itrsquos just to ensure survival. Wersquove obviously got a lot of outgoings with machinery rentals and buggy rentals and bills to play.Clubhouse staff have been put on furlough, according to Mr Brydon, but a greenkeeper continues to maintain the course, established in .Mr Brydon said the club has around  members, but ex-members have also been keen to show their concern.ldquoWersquove seen donations from as far away as Australia, said Mr Brydon. ldquoWersquove also had money from Aberdeen and from former members in Chepstow.A third of the clubrsquos income has traditionally come from visitors, said Mr Brydon, who explained the coursersquos appeal.ldquoItrsquos a really lovely course ndash the views and the scenery and the layout. A lot of the visitors have been coming for  years, he said.Mr Brydon put the chances of survival at around  per cent, adding: ldquoEverybody has got to remain positive, but there are so many unknowns at the moment.Outlining how much the club means to him, he said: ldquoIrsquove been a member for  years, so itrsquos a huge part of my le and my familyrsquos le. Itrsquos a spectacular place to be ndash we all take it for granted.Peebles Golf Club is one of the other clubs running a similar fundraising drive.

title: royal-mail-launches-thumbs-postie-campaign---get-involved
story: Royal Mail is asking its customers to show their appreciation for their postie by giving them a lsquothumbs uprsquo - from a safe two metres distance - as they go about their rounds.Heres what you need to know.Contact free deliveryA spokesman for the Royal Mail said: "The initiative is a simple way for the public to say thanks and stay connected with their local postmen and women, while respecting the Governmentrsquos social distancing rules."Giving a thumbs up is also a handy reminder not to reach out to try and take parcels direct from postmen and women to ensure contact free delivery."Royal Mailrsquos postmen and postwomen are at the heart of the communities in which they work. With the country observing Government advice to stay home, for many people their local postman or woman may be one of the few friendly faces they see each day."The delivery oflettersand parcels is an important way to keep connected for those who may be unable to leave their home."Thank you messagesThe move comes as postmen and women across the UK have been inundated with thank you messages and pictures from children and customers.As well as giving their posties a friendly thumbs up when they see them, Royal Mail is asking customers to share selfies with their thumbs up using the hashtag #ThumbsUpForYourPostie.Ricky McAulay, national service delivery director atRoyal Mail Group, said: ldquoWe know how much people like to say hi or have a chat with their postie on the doorstep.ldquoDuring this time, we need to find new ways of staying connected whilst also protecting our communities.ldquoWe hope that giving a thumbs up is a handy way of reminding people to keep a safe distance when we are out and about delivering the post.ldquoI would also like to thank our people for doing such a great job at this challenging time.The postal giant is also encouraging children to put lsquothumbs uprsquo pictures in their front window.Where can I get a template Templates are available to download from royalmail.

title: factory-gets-visited-army-ppe-can-sent-across-uk
story: A BORDERS factory boss says army trucks visited this month to collect personal protective equipmentfor hospital staff in England.Alistair Cameron, managing director of Scotmas Group, is overseeing the mass production of hand gels, PPE and water treatment technology from his companyrsquos Kelso premises.Customers include the NHS, the Royal Mail, the police and local authorities, according to Mr Cameron.The -year-old said: ldquoEverybody in the company realises just how critical what wersquore doing is.He added: ldquoOn Sunday [April ] the military came and took some of our products down to London where it was required for hospitals.Scotmas Group is split into two isions ndash Scotmas Water Treatment and Pyramid Travel Products.Collectively, they are making products which help key workers perform their duties during the coronavirus pandemic.By the end of the month, Mr Cameron expects a total of , bottles of hand gel will have been made, following a signicant rise in production at the Pinnaclehill Industrial Estate site.The hand gel, intended to offer four hoursrsquo protection after each use, will benefit postmen and women, police officers and council employees, according to Mr Cameron.Hospitals will not use the gel, said Mr Cameron, because ldquothey require an alcohol sanitiser.The NHS has been purchasing other products, however, including PPE and water treatment kit, Mr Cameron revealed.ldquoWersquore already working with  NHS trusts throughout the UK, providing water disinfectant treatments, said Mr Cameron.He said treatment plants are being set up in some of the temporary hospitals which have been built to handle virus patients.ldquoIn most cases, the sites chosen for these hospitals are simply not designed to cope with the rigours of a healthcare environment, so it is vital that the water is treated effectively, Mr Cameron said.Some of the products collected by the armywere being delivered to the emergency Nightingale hospital in London, Mr Cameron said.Staff in Kelso have performed admirably in recent weeks, according to Mr Cameron, despite the increase in workload.ldquoOur staff have been absolutely fantastic ndash theyrsquove never shirked from doing whatrsquos needed, he said.Meanwhile, in Selkirk, the local branch of the Guthrie Group has been supplying PPE to the Borders General Hospitaland key workers, according to manager Alan Skeldon.ldquoLocal companies have been great so far trying to buy from us and hopefully that will continue after this period of uncertainty, said Mr Skeldon.Reflecting on the delivery to the BGH, he said: ldquoObviously those guys are key at the moment and itrsquos good to make sure theyrsquore safe - and the feedback has been good as well.

title: royal-family-share-chocolate-cupcake-recipe-celebrate-queen-elizabeths-94th-birthday
story: The Royal Pastry Chefs have shared arecipe to make chocolate cupcakes and celebrate The Queens th birthday.In a statement made via Facebook, The Royal Family said: "Happy birthday to Her Majesty!"To celebrate The Queens birthday we are sharing a chocolate cupcake recipe from The Royal Pastry Chefs."If you or a loved one are celebrating a special occasion during isolation why not treat yourself to some#royalbakes  Remember to share your creations with us!"Heres how to make them.Ingredients cake sponges - g vinegarml milkml vegetable oilg butter eggsml of vanilla essenceg of self-raising flourof cocoa powderg caster sugarg bicarbonate of sodag white chocolate chipscupcake casesIngredients Buttercream Toppingg of high percentage dark chocolateg butterg icing sugarOption to also use Royal icing, instead of buttercream:Royal icing available pre-made in shops.Add food colouring to create dferent coloursCake sponge method:Preheat the oven to  CCombine the flour, sugar, cocoa powder and bicarbonate of soda into a mixing bowlWhisk the eggs in a separate jug, with the vanilla essence, melted butter, oil, milk and vinegarSlowly add the wet mixture into the dry mixture, little by littleEnsure the batter is smooth with no lumpsFinally add the chocolate chips Lay the cupcake cases onto a trayUse a metal spoon to equally ide the mixture into the casesBake for around - minutes, take out of the oven when golden and springy on touchLeave to coolButtercream icing methodCream the sugar and butter together, until light and creamyAdd in the warm melted chocolateIf you have a piping bag to hand, pipe the icing on the top of cakes for decoration Royal icing methodIf decorating with royal icing, roll the icing out and cut into circular disksLay the disc over the cupcake and mould to required shapeEat and enjoy!

title: bgh-site-gets-new-drive-through-centre-virus-testing
story: A NEW drive-through test centre has been set up at the Borders General Hospitalto identy health staff with coronavirus.The facility, located at the main car park, will offer tests to workers with appointments.It replaces a previous test centre where on the BGH site.Tests will mainly be given to health and social care staff, according to NHS Borders.A health board statement reads: "A temporary drive-through COVID- testing centre has been set up on the BGH site, positioned in the main carpark."A testing facility had previously been available at another location on the BGH site, however this new arrangement ensures further staff and patient safety and convenience."The drive through testing centre will predominantly be used for Health and Social Care staff testing at this time."It is important to note that attending this facility is by appointment only and people should not turn up without having been invited to do so."If anyone has symptoms of coronavirus, they are advised to stay at home for seven days.The most common symptoms are a new persistent cough and a fever high temperature .According to NHS Borders, your symptoms worsen during home isolation or are no better after sevendays then you should phone NHS  on .You should no longer call your GP practice regarding coronavirus symptoms.Full guidance and information is available on NHS Informrsquos coronavirus page.

title: borders-artist-runs-online-classes-lockdown
story: A BORDERS artist has spent lockdown running online art classes from the comfort of her home.Maria Koeva, an architect, began the Easy Sketching Club Art Challenge on April  to encourage people to pick up a brush, pencil, or pastel.The Melrose resident said: "Everyones grateful for the opportunity to keep occupied and boost their skills."Every day, Maria issues a prompt to let participants know what the classs theme will be, giving them a chance to prepare.She said: "As I cant do the workshops in person, for my sake, and attendants, I decided to run them online."Art and painting have always been a good way to spend your time."And when people dont know where to start, having the prompts helps them to plan ahead."I have my own preference but Im trying to show dferent styles, using pencils, pastels, water colours, so everyone can join in."Maria, originally from Moscow, Russia, started the Easy Sketching Club in October last year. She offered in-person classes through Natural Crafts, Melrose, and afterschool clubs at Melrose Primary School.For each day of the challenge, Maria sets a dferent topic. So far, the artists have covered themes including the Eildons, interiors, Russian dolls, parrots and ndash immediately prior to Marias interview with this newspaper ndash fast food."My favourite has to be the kingfisher shyndash it turned out so well," said Maria. "The burger I did today was fun to do, too."Those taking part in the daily art project cover a ied age range. One family span three generations - a daughter, mother and grandmother - all participating whileobserving social-distancing guidelines.Marias page has  followers, and the numbers watching her livestreams y each day, but Maria told us: "There are roughly  people who participate. And the people who do it, feedback has been good."Although the lockdown has meant Maria is unable to run her workshops as normal, she has found some benefits to being at home."Ive always painted," she said, "and Im an architect by trade so Ive always painted in some way or another."But now I have the opportunity to paint more regularly."I really enjoy doing the workshops but Id run them in a dferent format in the future. As long as there is a demand for them, Ill keep going."The Easy Sketching Club Art Challenge is set to finish at the end of the month, with one lucky artist winning a pound voucher to use at Simply Delicious, Melrose, once lockdown restrictions have been lted.The winner of the voucher will be chosen at random from all the pieces of art Maria will have received over the course of the challenge, and participants will have some extra time to catch up on any challenges they missed.For more information, and to join the challenge, visit: www.facebook easysketchingclub

title: peebles-ruined-litter-says-eco-hero
story: A DISAPPOINTED environmentalist has criticised litter-droppers in Peeblesshire following his most recent clean-up effort.Jeremy Stuart-Menteth, , frequently undertakes tidy-ups in the Peebles area.But now the retired osteopath has become fed up with some residents selfish habits.He said: "Theres an exorbitant amount of litter ndash I think people are becoming litter blind."Since moving to the region in , Mr Stuart-Menteth has tried to pick up any rubbish he has come across.However, the Stobo resident has become increasingly frustrated by the mess, believing it puts Peeblesshire "in a bad light".He said: "Peebles in particular is becoming bad for it, and I think its a reflection on society as a whole."Weve seen reports on vandalism in the town, and litters one step from that. Theres no respect."Most of the rubbish probably dates to pre-lockdown, Mr Stuart-Menteth suspects.He has noticed fewer motorists around ndash who he believes are the main culprits of the littering ndash since local attractions have closed their doors.Mr Stuart-Menteth told us: "As with many others, Im fed up to the point of doing something."If I was looking for houses now, I would be put off."On a grander scale its not always noticeable, but it does get depressing to see."Its wrong how people mistreat the planet, especially when people see rubbish and dont pick it up ndash two wrongs dont make a right."A spokesman for Scottish Borders Council said: "We would ask all members of the public to play their part and place litter in a street bin or take it home to help keep our towns, villages and road side verges clean."Our Parks and Environment team continues to provide a street cleansing service, albeit resources are impacted at present by the coronavirus response."To report areas where litter is a problem, members of the public can use our website, or phone   ."

title: ice-cream-couple-using-van-help-vulnerable-folk
story: AN ICE cream van has stocked up with groceries and prescriptions to help Peeblesshire residents.Martha Gibson has run JM Ices for a decade, much to the delight of hundreds of kids.But now the popular Innerleithen resident has decided to requisition her vehicle in the fight against COVID-.She said: "Everyone knowsthey need anything they can come to Martha. Wersquove taken half the stock out of the van and filled it with bread, milk, pasta, rice, flour.Vulnerable folk and elderly people who cannot visit shops are able to draw on crucial assistance from Martha and her husband Brian.Martha said: ldquoThese folk canrsquot get out to do their shopping, so we do it for them. I now have two people on the van, one serving and the other dealing with cash. Wersquore following all the social distancing guidelines and using anti-bacterial products.ldquoMost elderly people only deal with cash, whereas others will just pay what they owe into my bank later."I ken mostly everyone and I know theyrsquoll pay me one way or another. As long as everyone gets what they need, thatrsquos whatrsquos important to me.Martha and Brian have been called ldquolesavers by grateful residents. Meanwhile, many families say the vans familiar tune has brought a bit of normality into the lives of confused children.And Marthas van boasts a bountul supply of goodies to "keep the bairns entertained".Martha said: ldquoWersquove stocked things like puzzles, bubbles, wee things for the bairns, just pocket money stuff for pound. Itrsquos not about making money for us, itrsquos about helping families.Serving their community is something that comes naturally to Martha and Brian, who say they always try to help those in need.Asked why she does so much, Martha said: ldquoI know what itrsquos like to struggle. Irsquove lived it, Irsquove been there. But I lived through a time when neighbours were neighbours."Yoursquod never go hungry - one family would give you a bag of tatties, the other some mince, between us wersquod put a meal together. You never did without.ldquoIrsquoll never forget that, and thatrsquos why I always help those in need. I do it because I want to gie a wee bit back to the community I love.And this is summed up perfectly by a member of the community who joined in the praise of this marvellous lady by writing: ldquoIf there were a lot more people like Martha, the world would be a better place.

title: netball-players-deliver-medicine-borders-town
story: NETBALL players in Peebles have been delivering medicine to people who cannot leave home.When sports fixtures were cancelled, members of the Stuart Netball Club contacted the Peebles Covid- Support Group.The athletes are now collecting prescriptions from Boots chemist and dropping them off in Peebles and nearby areas.Jodie Troup and Claire Mahon are among the players who jumped at the chance to lend a hand.They said: ldquoWe are thankful we can do something to support our community, especially when they have been so good at supporting us when we started our own club.ldquoWe deliver six days a week and we are helped by members of our households ."A few of the other girls help out on a Saturday to give us some time off.The women give up their time freely and pay for their own fuel.They said: ldquoMost people have been so lovely and very grateful. They really appreciate what wersquove done for them, which is so heart-warming."Some do need to remember we are only volunteers taking time out of our days and we donrsquot work for Boots. We do it because we want to help our community.

title: thousands-transport-workers-london-furloughed-monday
story: Thousands of transport workers in London are to be furloughed under moves to address the huge financial impact of the coronavirus lockdown.Transport for Londonsaid , staff whose work has been reduced or paused will be affected from Monday.TfL will be able to access funding from the Governmentrsquos Job Retention Scheme, saving the organisation an estimated pound. million every four weeks.Tube journeys have fallen by % and bus use by % since last monthrsquos lockdown, with people urged only to make essential journeys.TfL said its main source of income has almost ldquodisappeared.The Governmentrsquos scheme means TfL can access funding for % of the salary of furloughed staff up to a maximum of pound, a month, with the organisation making up the rest of
